content.text: From a BLACK SCREEN
--we’re in the middle of a confidential conversation.

dialogue: The screen says it’s an unimplemented trap but the dialogue box is wrong, it’s a system error.
About 10 minutes ago, we’ve been working it.

content.text: FADE IN:
We’ll get our bearings in a moment but right now we’re in the middle of a conversation taking place on a stage between STEVE JOBS, JOANNA HOFFMAN and ANDY HERTZFELD--all late- 20’s/early 30’s.

dialogue: The voice demo is flaky. I’ve been telling you that for--this thing is overbuilt.

content.text: TITLE:
Flint Auditorium
DeAnza Community College

dialogue: It worked last night, it worked the night before that, it worked three hours ago.
It’s not working now so just skip
Skip over--everything else is working. Skip over the voice demo.
I’m the person who can and I can’t.
I don’t know what that means.
(the demo is more than likely gonna crash)
You have to keep your voices down, Joel Pforzheimer is sitting out in the house.
I don’t care if--who’s Joel Pforzheimer?
GQ. He’s been shadowing you for a week, did you notice?
Just look like everything’s fine, he’s sitting out in the house.

content.text: We reveal the 2,600 seat house which in 40 minutes will be filled to capacity. We’re at the launch of the Mac.

There are hundreds of seats with “Reserved For” signs on them for the various Apple teams--”Macintosh”, “Apple II”, “Lisa”-- as well as hundreds of members of the press--”New York Times”, “Newsweek”, “Wall Street Journal”, “Financial Times of London”, “Le Monde”, etc. JOEL PFORZHEIMER is out there, credentials around his neck, and he gives a small wave to Steve and so are 50 or 60 ENGINEERS, DESIGNERS and MARKETERS who are observing the rehearsal from various vantage points.
Way in the back is CHRISANN BRENNAN, 31, and her daughter, LISA BRENNAN, 5, who’s tucked in a big coat.

STEVE, JOANNA and ANDY are standing in front of a giant screen showing a slide of the Mac. JOANNA is a beautiful, brilliant, dryly-funny Polish immigrant who speaks with a slight trace of an accent. ANDY is a sweet, cherubic young guy--if you put a bow and arrow in his hands he’d look like Cupid. Nobody has slept for days.

dialogue: Alright, what are your guys saying?
Some kind of race condition but we haven’t been able to track it down yet.
Is the synthesizer sampling fast enough?
No, so the rates are off and it keeps crashing.
It’s 20 seconds out of a two-hour launch, why not just cut it?
Two days ago we ran a Super Bowl ad that could’ve won the Oscar for Best Short Film.
There are more people who can tell you about the ad than can tell you who won the game.
I understand, but the ad said the Mac was gonna save the world, it didn’t say it was gonna say hello.

content.text: ANDREA CUNNINGHAM, a 26-year-old publicist for Apple, calls from the back--

dialogue: We’re gonna open the house in five.
We can recompile but if it’s a hardware problem we can’t get into the back.
You want to tell her or should I?
Why can’t he get into the machine?
What kind of special tools, just take a screwdriver.
He didn’t want users to be able to open it, you need special tools.
There are a hundred engineers walking around here, none of them have the tools?
In fairness, not many of them were issued the tools.

content.text: ANDY shrugs--

dialogue: I left them at the office, it was 3 A.M and--
What’s the first rule of a launch?
The other Andy, you’re right there, why would I
He needs to talk to you.

content.text: ANDREA CUNNINGHAM, the 26-year-old publicist, calls back--

dialogue: The exit signs have to be off or we’re not gonna get a full blackout.
We’ve spoken to the building manager and the fire marshal.
There’s absolutely no way they’re letting us turn the exit signs off.
I’ll pay whatever the fine is.
The fine is they’re gonna come in and tell everyone to leave.
You explained to the fire marshal that we’re in here changing the world?
I did, but unless we can also change the properties of fire he doesn’t care.
If a fire causes a stampede to the unmarked exits it will have been well worth it for those who survive. For those who don’t, less so but still pretty good.
I need it to go to black, real black, get rid of the exit signs and don’t let me know how you did it.

content.text: STEVE leaves the stage, followed by JOANNA and heads--

dialogue: You need special tools to open the Mac?
You knew it was a closed system.

content.text: JOANNA opens a door marked “STEVE JOBS” and gives STEVE a push into--
The room’s been set aside as a place for Steve to chill, be alone and prepare during rehearsals and before the big presentation.
There’s a Mac (the original Mac) on a small table.
There’s also a large, unopened carton that was recently delivered.

dialogue: And if you keep alienating people for no reason there’s gonna be no one left for it to say hello to.
It’s not for no reason. We blow this and IBM will own the next 50 years like a Batman villain. Remember the phone company?

That’s what Bell was called, the phone company. IBM will be the computer company and in 10 years they’ll be the information company and that’s very bad for the human race so we don’t have time to be polite or realistic ‘cause if we are, this company’s next product launch will be held in front of 26 people and a stringer from the Alameda County Shopper’s Guide.
We--listen--we haven’t advertised the voice software. We could pull it out of the demo and no one would be disappointed. Do you want to try being reasonable just, you know, to see what it feels like?
You can tell me how unimportant it is but if the computer doesn’t say hello then neither will John Sculley who, I promise you, agrees with me.
Sculley’s not gonna cancel the launch ‘cause he’s not insane.
He’s also not a hack and when it comes to the Macintosh he’s gonna do what I ask him to do. What is in this box?
Nothing you need to worry about, don’t even open it.

content.text: STEVE opens the flaps on the box and pulls out an issue of Time magazine. “Machine of the Year” is on the cover with a picture of a computer. It’s a carton full of copies of Time.

dialogue: What the fuck is--why is there a carton of--who did this?

--doesn’t matter--thought it would be a good idea to have copies of that Time cover available at everyone’s seat. It was nipped in the bud and all the copies are being taken out of the building-- they’re probably already out of the building so...problem solved.

Somebody thought it would be a good idea to, like, enthusiastically hand over copies of Time with a not- a-Macintosh on the cover at the launch of the Macintosh? What are they handing out at Hewlett- Packard, a bushel of apples with my face on them?
--that since the computer is Man of the Year that that’s good for our business but like I said I’m having them removed from the building.
What I’d like you to do with them is to take them, all 2600 copies, and stack them on Kottke’s desk and tell him Steve says, “Happy New Year to you.”

I gave Michael Moritz full access, the whole campus. Bandley, Apple II, Lisa, I gave him Sculley, Markkula, I gave him Woz, I gave him everybody. Betrayal, thy name is Michael Moritz and Bozo, thy name is Daniel Kottke. What should I call the person who thought it would be a good idea to hand these out?
I’m not telling you who it was, it was done without malice, it’s been taken care of, you have a half-hour and we have things to talk about.
Like a million in the first 90 days--
Twenty thousand a month after that.
--because this is my field. I am begging you to manage expectations out there.
We’re not gonna sell a million in the first 90 days.
Everyone, everyone, everyone. Everyone is waiting for the Mac.
Maybe, but what happens when they find out that for twenty-four ninety-five there’s nothing you can do with it?

content.text: STEVE stares at her...

dialogue: We were competitive at 1500 but once you replaced the Motorola 6809 with the 68000--
--which is what supports menus, windows, point and click, high res graphics--
Yeah, ‘cause everyone needs rectangles with rounded corners.
Coach lands on the runway at the exact same time as first class.
I don’t have the first fucking idea what that means but this is how it got to $2500.
Which is the price point on the PC which can do a lot more.

Who’s gonna want a PC once--what idiot is gonna want--if I need to tell you there’s a spot on your shirt I point to the spot, I don’t say there’s a spot 14 centimeters down from the collar and 3 centimeters to the right of the second button while I try to remember what the command is for club soda, that’s not how a person’s mind works.
If the goal was ease of use, maybe you should’ve given it some memory.

You can complain about memory or you can complain about price but you can’t do both at the same time. Memory is what costs money. And I’m glad you’re telling me your feelings about the Mac now because we have a half-hour left, we can redesign it.
Look at their faces when they see what it is. They won’t know what they’re looking at or why they like it but they’ll know they want it.
Not instantly. When people heard “Rite of Spring” they tore the chairs out of the theater, they didn’t buy the record.
“Rite of Spring” happens to be the most revolutionary and provocative symphony of the last century.
Yes, exactly, but Igor Stravinsky didn’t say he was gonna sell 20,000 units a month.
It was 1913, there weren’t--I don’t know why we’re talking about Stravinsky when--
--I’ve been properly sodomized by Dan Kottke in Time magazine.
Look, obviously--let me say this-- obviously Daniel didn’t think he was doing anything wrong.
By talking to Moritz about it?

You said--when you told me the story, you said, “Dan, did Michael Moritz ask you if I had a daughter named Lisa?” and Dan said, “Yeah” and you said, “What did you tell him?” and Dan said, “Yes.” My point was that he answered you simply and honestly because he didn’t think he’d done anything wrong.
Except, Joanna, except--I don’t have a daughter named Lisa!
And this story is now about how I’m denying paternity and took a blood test!
And that’s why there’s a picture of a--I don’t know what the fuck that is--that’s why there’s a picture of a PC on the cover instead of a picture of me and the Mac.
I don’t know what to tell you. I was supposed to be Time magazine’s Man of the Year and then Dan Kottke was born.
They’re out in the hall. They’ve been sitting in the back of the auditorium since seven this morning, she wants to talk to you.
I’m not having a session with her right now.

We issued 335 press credentials for the launch, Steve, you piss off Chrisann and she’s gonna stand in the lobby and give 335 interviews and you, pal, will be longing for the halcyon days of Dan Kottke.
Lemme get this over with. But don’t leave, you’re gonna stay here.
No, there’s less chance of a scene if you stay here, she’ll be cool.
I find this all excruciatingly personal and I’m not staying.
I don’t want to be in a room alone with Chrisann. Come on, this is me and you.

content.text: STEVE goes to the door, opens it and steps out into--
--where CHRISANN BRENNAN and LISA are waiting.

dialogue: This is a surprise, why don’t you come on in.

content.text: CHRISANN takes LISA’s hand to lead her--

dialogue: Yes, I’m not going to leave her in the hallway.
Okay. It’s a safe hallway, but...anyway--

content.text: They walk back into--

dialogue: --you remember Joanna Hoffman, she’s the head of marketing for the Mac.
Nice to see you. Hello, Lisa. We’ve met before and you told me you liked the way I talked and that was my favorite thing anyone’s ever said to me.
Yes I am. Do you know where that is?
(pointing to the top of an imaginary globe)
I think you’re thinking of the North Pole.
Well we’re a little pressed for time, so--
Why?...do you want to leave when
I’m going to check in with Hertzfeld.
We’re trying to get a computer to say hello but right now it’s being very shy. Would you come help me?
My dad named a computer after me.

content.text: STEVE stops himself and sees the looks coming from both CHRISANN and JOANNA.

dialogue: That, actually--do you know what a coincidence is, Lisa? Like if you met someone, if you made a new friend and her name was Lisa too, that would be a coincidence. Lisa stands for “Local Integrated System Architecture”. L-I-S-A. It’s a coincidence.
Come. Let’s make that computer say hi.

content.text: LISA’s still absorbing the “Lisa” information...

dialogue: So it was the other way around--I was named after the computer?
Nothing was named after anybody, it’s a coincidence.

content.text: JOANNA and LISA exit.

dialogue: What’s the matter with you?! Why are you telling her these things? Why are you still telling her I’m her father?
A judge told her you’re her father--
--and where the hell do you get off telling Time magazine that I’ve slept with 28% of the men in America.
That‘s not remotely what I said.
First of all, can I tell you something about Time magazine?
I believe it’s a training facility for paid assassins.
”’28% of the male population of the United States could be the father.’”
I wasn’t saying you’ve slept with 28% of American men, I was using an algorithm based on the blood test which said there was a 94.1% chance that I’m the father.
You’re trying to publicly paint me as a slut and a whore.
Believe me, I’m not trying to publicly do anything with you.
Two-million people read Time, how am
It would’ve been more if they’d put me on the cover but Dan Kottke
I said I applied for welfare yesterday. The Time article said your Apple stock is worth 441 million dollars. And I wanted to ask you how you felt about that.
Well...I feel like Apple stock is being dramatically undervalued. This would be a good time to get in.
Your daughter and her mother are on welfare.
We’re living in a hovel in Menlo Park. We can’t pay the heating bills, she sleeps in a parka. Your daughter is
Because as reported by Time magazine I’ve slept with 28% of the men in America--
--all of them exactly nine months before Lisa was born.

content.text: There’s a KNOCK at the door and JOANNA opens it--
STEVE steps out into--
--where ANDY HERTZFELD is waiting along with some members of his team. LISA slips into the dressing room from the hallway without STEVE much noticing.

dialogue: Excuse me for saying hello to my friend who thinks you’re a dick.
No. It’s got a one in six chance of working.

content.text: It should be noted there are a number of people--YOUNG ENGINEERS--standing around and witnessing Steve beat up Andy.

dialogue: We’re not a pit crew at Daytona, this can’t be fixed in seconds.
You didn’t have seconds, you had three weeks. The universe was created in a third of that time.
Well someday you’ll have to tell us how you did it.

content.text: JOANNA can’t help a smile and small laugh. STEVE looks at her...

dialogue: Here’s what I’m going to do. I’m going to announce the names of everyone who designed the launch demo--I’m gonna introduce everyone and ask them to stand up. The bag was designed by Susan Kare, the Macintosh font that’s scrolling across the screen was designed by Steve Capps, the starry night and the skywriting was Bruce Horn, MacPaint, MacWrite, Alice, down to the calculator and then I’m going to say the voice demo that didn’t work was designed by Andy Hertzfeld.

content.text: ANDY laughs a little for a moment but STEVE stares at him and ANDY realizes he’s serious. The others are looking down and trying to make themselves look busy but there’s no saving Andy here.

dialogue: Five in six is your chance of surviving first round of Russian roulette and you’ve reversed those odds so unless you want to be disgraced in front of your friends, family, colleagues, stockholders and the press, I wouldn’t stand here arguing, I’d go try to get some more bullets out of the gun.

content.text: ANDY nods to his team that they should come with him and get back to work. As the team starts to walk away, STEVE sees one of the engineers take a diskette out of his shirt pocket and a light bulb goes off in his head.

dialogue: Stop. You. What size shirt do you wear?
What size--does anyone know what size shirt he wears? Does anyone know what size shirt I wear?
Does anyone know where the closest psychiatrist is?
The disk fits in your pocket--I need a shirt with a breast pocket, I can take it out on stage.
I need a white shirt in my size with a breast pocket.
Yes. Which one of the no stores that are open at 8:45 do you want me to have someone run to and return from in 15 minutes?
Go out in the lobby, find someone my size who’s wearing a white shirt and tell them I’ll trade them for a free computer and they get to keep my shirt.
Does it have to be a white shirt, is blue okay?
No, the Mac is beige, I’m beige, the disk is blue and the shirt has to be white. Andy?

content.text: STEVE looks at ANDY and mimes rolling the cartridge of a revolver and sticking it to his own head along with sound effects. ANDY and his team take off as STEVE heads back into--

dialogue: I tried to get it to say hello but it’s shy.

content.text: STEVE didn’t even notice she was there. He takes a breath and smiles...
CHRISANN points to the Mac that’s sitting on a table--

dialogue: What are people going to do with it?
Lisa, how old are you now?
Come sit here for a minute. You know what this is?

content.text: LISA sits at the table in front of the Mac--

dialogue: It’s a computer. Can I borrow your hand for a second?

content.text: STEVE puts his hand on top of LISA’s and demonstrates the mouse.

dialogue: Point that arrow...and click. You don’t have to but if you want you can play with it. Nothing you can do will break it so just do whatever you want with it.

content.text: While STEVE and CHRISANN continue, LISA becomes engaged with the computer. She can hear her parents of course, but the computer and what she’s doing with it become a welcome distraction.

dialogue: I’m paying you exactly what the court ordered me to pay you.
I’m not the one who decided on that amount.
And I’m asking you how you feel--if you feel alright, if it feels alright to you--that your daughter and her mother--
--your daughter, who’s sitting right there--and her mother are on welfare while you’re worth 441 million dollars for making that?
I’m proud to say that Apple donates free computers to underfunded schools and we’ll be doing more of--
Apple donates millions of dollars worth of computers to schools.
Imagine an underprivileged kid who has their favorite teacher with them 24 hours. We’re minutes away from being able to do that.
In your head was that an answer to my question?
I wasn’t the one who sued you for child support, San Mateo County sued you.
No let me explain what happened, ‘cause I have plenty of time right now.

content.text: There’s a knock on the door and ANDREA opens it--

dialogue: Excuse me, you have a visitor.

content.text: STEVE (WOZ) WOZNIAK sticks his head in the door. WOZ is amiable. He’s not looking for trouble and while he’s an undisputed genius, he doesn’t have Steve’s anger or Steve’s polish.

dialogue: I just wanted to say good luck. Hey Chrisann.

content.text: STEVE goes out into--

dialogue: I just wanted to say good luck.
You should see the crowd outside. It’s like...the crowd is like, you know...

content.text: STEVE waits patiently until he can’t anymore--

dialogue: I can’t really wait for you to come up with the metaphor, man.
Yeah so listen, I wanted to ask you a favor.
Can you acknowledge the Apple II team in your remarks?
Just an acknowledgement, have them stand up.
It’d be a morale booster. Just a mention so they can get a round of applause.
Can we stick a pin in this for a minute--
I’m just talking about an acknowledgement for the team.
I’ve got Chrisann in there, I’ll see you in just a second.

content.text: STEVE goes back into--

dialogue: I didn’t take the DNA test voluntarily, I took it because the board was worried you were going to sue me.
The board. Was worried you were going to sue me before the IPO.

The members of the board, individually, believe that you’re deranged, Chris. They were worried that you were going to sue me before the IPO and endanger the stock price. Fourteen of the greatest minds in business were literally weighing the possibility that you could affect the economy. So I took a blood test, which I obviously wouldn’t have done if I didn’t think it would prove conclusively and for all time that I am not--
--and frankly I think telling her otherwise is child abuse.
You skipped over the part where the test proved
Would you like to be put in a casket and buried if there’s a 94.1% chance that you’re dead?

Steve, let’s not be ridiculous. And if I wanted to embarrass you, if I wanted to embarrass Apple and if I wanted to extort money from you it’s not like I’d have to invent anything. Humiliate me all you want but you don’t need to look far to see living reminders that I’m in your life and you’re in mine and neither of us is disappearing.

Check out who isn’t on the cover of Time because one reporter--one-- found out a fraction of one thing, a small fraction of one symptom of your progressing Narcissistic Personality Disorder. The board's right to be scared of me.

content.text: STEVE, without looking at it, takes the Mac that Lisa’s been working on by the handle and turns it around so Chrisann can see the screen and puts it forcefully back on the table. Lisa’s made a painting. The kind of thing only a parent could love, but a painting.

dialogue: You asked me what people are going to do with it. They’re gonna do that.

content.text: There’s a KNOCK on the door and JOANNA enters with a white shirt.
STEVE starts to take off his shirt...
Then STEVE looks at Lisa’s painting which he hadn’t seen when he turned it around for Chrisann...he’s seeing it for the first time and he almost involuntarily stops unbuttoning his shirt.
STEVE can’t help but let out a laugh and smile at that. There’s an emotion happening inside of him he doesn’t quite understand...
STEVE keeps looking at the screen, then glancing at Lisa...

dialogue: Push that key and the “S” at the same time.

content.text: LISA does as she’s told as the “SAVE” box comes up.
She does. “L-I-S-A B-R-E-N-N-A-N.”

dialogue: Do you know which box says “Save”?

content.text: LISA points to the right box.

dialogue: Right. Go ahead and click on it.

content.text: She does.
After a moment, STEVE continues changing his shirt...

dialogue: I’ll put some money in your account. And I’ll buy you a new house, someplace near a decent school.
Can you teach me more things?

content.text: This hits STEVE and CHRISANN in two different ways but it hits them both.

dialogue: Lisa, wait for me in the hall please.

content.text: LISA starts to put on her coat, which is a little bulky and tough for a kid--

dialogue: You can put on your coat in the hall.

content.text: But LISA didn’t hear him--she’s already out the door.

dialogue: I just want to know, when you say you’re going to put money in my account, how much we’re talking about?
You don’t mind if we discuss this in front of you?
It’s a school day. She needs to be in school.
I’m gonna give you whatever you need.
It was good to see you again. I’m sorry, I don’t remember your name.
Are you and Steve together now?
As Steve said, I run marketing for the Macintosh team.
You seem like a very capable woman.
And you have a good sense of humor. Why do you choose to work for an asshole?

content.text: CHRISANN doesn’t laugh.

dialogue: And if I spent every hour of every day with people who were dumber than I am I bet I’d be an asshole too.

content.text: CHRISANN nods...

dialogue: Yeah, I guess you would be.

content.text: CHRISANN exits.

dialogue: You two are so good together, I don’t know why you couldn’t make it work.

content.text: STEVE’s tying his tie.

dialogue: Woz wants me to acknowledge the Apple II team.
You must be able to see that she looks like you.
I don’t want to insult Woz, I just think it’s backward-looking at exactly the wrong moment.

I heard what you said, Joanna. We’re about to do this thing--at 9:41 the planet’s gonna shift on its axis, nigh and forever. The two most significant events of the 20th Century--the Allies win the War and this. This. So maybe right now isn’t the very best time to scold me for not being a better father to a kid who’s not my kid. The test--
I don’t care what the test said--
I don’t care about 94.1% or the insane algorithm you used to get to 28% of American men--
I’m buying her a new house, I’m
There’s a small girl who believes you’re her father, that’s all, that’s all the math there is. She believes it. What are you going to do about that?

content.text: STEVE’s done with his tie. He puts a disk in his shirt pocket and tries taking it in and out. Then he grabs his jacket--

dialogue: God sent His only son on a suicide mission but we like Him anyway ‘cause He made trees. We’re gonna sell a million units in the first 90 days, twenty thousand a month after that, so maybe you could gimme a break, Ms. Hoffman.

content.text: They look at each a moment before STEVE exits out into--

On the other side of the wall is a full auditorium--2,600 people--and the energy is like a rock concert about to start. Staff and well-wishers (everybody’s young) line the hallway. WOZ is waiting and STEVE motions to walk with him--

dialogue: There’s nothing in that vending machine that won’t kill you.
Let’s take a walk. I haven’t been outside since Friday.
I don’t think I ask for a lot.

content.text: They head out the doors and onto--

dialogue: I know and I could say I’m gonna do it and then just not do it but I don’t wanna lie to you.
Right, and I appreciate that, but you could also say you’re gonna do it and then do it, couldn’t you?
I think the best thing would be for me to say I’m not gonna do it and then not do it, you good with that?
I have nothing but free time right now.
After the meeting in Maui the Apple II team was upset and angry and down and you know why?
Because the Apple II wasn’t mentioned even once.
The Apple II wasn’t mentioned even-- yes, that’s, you have it, that’s right.
They know that, they know it wasn’t. Look, I don’t want to make a big deal out of this--
The Apple II is what was, my friend.

The Apple II is what pays the bills around here and has for seven years and when you disrespect these people you are doing something wrong. It’s bad business but it’s also, you know, it’s just, it’s you know--

Okay, first, if we’re gonna talk about this, this, in the last remaining minutes before the launch which by itself is blowing my fuckin’ mind--if we’re gonna talk about this could you not frame yourself as a friend of the working man, most of whom I made into millionaires? ‘
Cause you’re not talking about them, you’re talking about you.

I’ve never, Steve, I’ve never cared about--I take issue with that. I’ve never cared about credit and you know it. I’m talking about them and I gave away stock options to people whose names you can’t remember.
They need to make me remember their names.
If you embarrass these people you’re gonna see a brain drain at this company, my brother. Markkula took you off the Lisa, not them and not me, so
Markkula took me off the Lisa because of his strong religious objection to making it good.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

It’s the garage. It’s completely tricked out with all the crude but cool-looking things a group of young geniuses would have while inventing a new computer. The only light is coming from a couple of tensor lamps on a workbench.
A younger STEVE and WOZ are standing in front of a huge diagram showing several parts of the Apple II from different angles.
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Now I gave you everything you wanted on the Apple II.
You don’t ask for a lot? There wasn’t a single fight you lost.
Do you concede that the slots
(are the reason for the success of)
We can’t possibly still be talking about the slots, man, it’s been seven years and--
I have a point. The eight slots on
You’re still doing it, you’re talking about the slots, there’s something wrong
This argument started in the garage!

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: Why would you only want two slots?
With eight slots you can--this is a huge deal that we were able to put in eight slots.
I appreciate the engineering but it’s not what we’re doing.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: And thank God I won that argument ‘cause--
--the open system is what people love about the machine and it’s why it sold and still sells.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: An open system, we’re not doing an open system.
Of course we are. That’s what people want and the breakthrough on the Apple II is--
People don’t know what they want until you show it to them. Edison didn’t do market research on the light bulb versus the candle.
I think it went without saying that people would rather flip a switch than, you know, burn whale oil. Let me explain this world to you. Serious users--
You live on the Planet Wozniak.

Serious users want to customize and modify, they want to jack it up, they want hardware engineers like me to expand its capabilities, okay? Keyboards for music, better sound boards, better display boards--

STEVE looks at WOZ...

As soon as the room is empty--

dialogue: I’ve been trying to get an answer on--

PARC stands for Palo Alto Research Center--Xerox PARC. In the ‘70s they came up with something called “Gooey”--G-U-I--Graphical User Interface. Instead of typing commands they used the metaphor of a desktop and roughly the same idea as a McDonald’s cash register. You press a button with a picture of a cheeseburger.
And you were shown the technology.
And used it in the Macintosh.
You can draw a line from Xerox PARC to the Mac.
What would you say--Steve, I’m not saying this but what would you say to someone who said you stole the Macintosh from Xerox?
Do you know who invented the piano?
Do you know who wrote “Moonlight Sonata”?
That’s what I’d say. I’ll see you after.

content.text: STEVE heads out of the room and back into--
--where ANDY HERTZFELD and JOANNA are waiting for him.
They begin walking toward the door that leads to the stage--

dialogue: Hear me, we’re a computer company, we can’t start late.

content.text: They walk through a door and are--

They’re behind the giant screen on which the whole presentation will be projected. Several Macs and their operators are at tables. We can hear the audience’s energy. And we can see an ENGINEER with a small crowbar trying to find a spot to open the back of another Mac while a couple of other ENGINEERS stand around it with screwdrivers.

dialogue: Wait, you’re gonna demo a 128 computer on a 512?
And you think that’s borderline unethical?
Please--you have to tell me why it’s so important for it to say hello.
Hollywood. They made computers scary things.
You see how this reminds you of a friendly face? That the disk slot is a goofy grin? It’s warm and it’s playful and inviting and it needs to say hello. It needs to say hello because it can.

content.text: We hear a few dozen members of the audience--seated up in the balcony--start to stamp their feet and clap their hands in rhythm, rock concert style. The few dozen turn into a few hundred.
STEVE, JOANNA and ANDY silently take it in...

dialogue: We’re not committing fraud. The 512 is gonna ship in under a year. Will you absolve me of your Eastern European disapproval?
The computer in 2001 said hello all the time and it still scared the shit out of--
Just for this. And just for now.

content.text: The house lights go out and we hear the audience break into THUNDEROUS APPLAUSE.
We hear a WOMAN’s voice over the PA system and see her speaking into a mic backstage--

content.text: We see the silhouette of MARKKULA walking to the podium and we’ll be able to hear his opening remarks without paying much attention to them.

dialogue: Alright. Okay. Go make a dent in the universe, Steven.
See you in a couple of hours.

content.text: JOANNA heads off and disappears as MARKKULA’s opening remarks continue. STEVE waits...

dialogue: The last three run-throughs we’ve introduced the Mac exactly 41 minutes into the--
The clock on the Mac needs to read 9:41.
The clock’s gonna read whatever the time is, it’s a clock.

content.text: STEVE takes a moment, nods, and turns to go head to where he’s supposed to wait backstage.

He sees a welcoming sight--the first one of the day. It’s JOHN SCULLEY. SCULLEY’s a handsome and easygoing man about 20 years older than Steve. He’s got a bottle of wine and two glasses. STEVE smiles and walks over to him as the opening remarks continue in the background.
STEVE hugs SCULLEY and they speak quietly--

dialogue: Thank merciful God, the cavalry’s shown up.
‘Cause I hear you’ve been worse than usual this morning and I didn’t think that was possible. So I’ve been dispatched to be the Steve Whisperer. This is a ‘55 Margaux.

content.text: SCULLEY starts pouring two glasses--

dialogue: Is it my imagination or have you started to dress like me?
It was a bad idea to have Markkula open with quarterly reports. Instead of having Markkula open we could have just dropped water on the audience.

content.text: SCULLEY laughs a little--

dialogue: You know, just big 10,000 gallon tanks of cold water dropped from the ceiling, save Mike some money on index cards.
I don’t know, no one’s ever asked that question.

content.text: STEVE laughs a little.

dialogue: You’re the only person who sees the world the same way I do.
No one sees the world the same way you do.
I’m like Julius Caesar, John, I’m surrounded by enemies.
Only because you see to it they are.
I think it’s a good board but if you want me to push ‘em out one by one we can talk about that.
I want you to push ‘em out all at once. Through a window if it’s the nearest exit. The looks on their faces when we showed ‘em the spot?
I couldn’t see their faces ‘cause they were banging their heads on the table.
Some of them were frozen like they’d just seen “Springtime for Hitler.”
My highlight was the silence that was broken by, “It’s supposed to be a play on the Orwell book, right?” Yeah, the spot’s called “1984.”

Yesterday, the day after it airs-- once--the publisher of Ad Week calls it the best commercial of all time. Of all time. And it is and if anyone ever does one better it’s gonna be Chiat/Day who the board wanted to replace and it’s gonna be Lee Clow who the board thought was out of his mind. Now listen to this, you ready?

content.text: The “1984” ad starts playing on the screen--we’re seeing it from behind--and as soon as it starts the CROWD ROARS.

dialogue: They wanted to fire Lee Clow.
Did we use skinheads as extras? A couple of people have told me that.
We paid skinheads? I have skinheads on my payroll?
Not currently I don’t think, but--
They had a look he wanted.
‘Kay let’s keep that to ourselves ‘cause it might offend some of our customers.
All the ones who aren’t skinheads.
My point is they didn’t get it.
They didn’t get it, they didn’t like it, they tried to pull it, they were wrong, we were right and that boardroom is a big bowl of scares-the-living-shit-outta-me.
I’m running your pass blocking on the board. Who else knows?
That we paid terrorists to be in our TV commercial.
They were wrong about the ad but it’s a good board, they’re good people.
Their only problem, their problem is that they’re people. People...the nature of people...is something to be overcome.
When I was running Pepsi we had a lot of success focusing on 18-to-55 year olds who aren’t members of violent hate
We’re almost there. About two more minutes of quarterly reports.

dialogue: Chrisann came and she brought Lisa.
I’m going back and forth on the Dylan. I might quote a different verse.
“For the loser now will be later to win,” which is what we have now.
“It’ll soon shake your windows and rattle your walls”.
We’re leading a geek revolution and not the French Revolution, what else?
“Come mothers and fathers throughout the land.
And don’t criticize what you can’t understand. Your sons and your daughters--”

“--are beyond your command”, I just lost a hundred bucks to Andy Hertzfeld. He said you’d change it to that verse. We’ve got 45 seconds left and I want to use it to ask you a question. Why do people who were adopted feel like they were rejected instead of selected?
“Your sons and your daughters are beyond your command. Your old road is rapidly aging. So go fuck yourself ‘cause my name is Steve Jobs and the times, they are a- changin’”.
‘Cause it’s not like the baby is born and the parents look and say, “Nah, we’re not interested in this one.” On the other hand, someone did choose you.
As long as clocks work the past will destroy itself by being the past.
No, you have to consciously get rid of it or the past will be the present as well.

content.text: And STEVE’s so happy that someone’s articulated this--

dialogue: That’s exactly--see?--that’s exactly what--you’re the only one-- God--that’s what I meant. You’re the only one who sees the world the way I do.
What inspired Hertzfeld to make that bet?
He was warning me that being your father figure could be dangerous. I can start replacing the board with more Steve-friendly members.
You’re the company, you have control.
I wasn’t talking about the company.
You find out that you were out of the loop when the most crucial events in your life were set in motion. As long as you have control...I don’t understand people who give it up.
He said being a father figure to me was dangerous?
He didn’t mean anything by it.
Keep your hundred bucks, I’m sticking with the first verse.

content.text: He doesn’t get weepy but that always means a lot to STEVE.

dialogue: It’s my pleasure to introduce my friend and the CEO of Apple, John Sculley.
Lisa made a painting on the Mac.

content.text: HARD CUT TO:
BLACK
--and “The Times They Are a-Changin’” crashes in.

But this isn’t Bob Dylan’s version--it’s a woman singing and instead of an acoustic guitar it’s a slightly fuller and slightly more up-tempo arrangement. It’s not a Vietnam-era protest song but a more contemporary and literal statement.
We listen to the beginning of the song with the screen in black before we--
FADE IN:
PETER JENNINGS - ABC NEWS
As the song continues--

dialogue: We turn to “Money Matters” and Barry Peterson.

The Macintosh, Apple’s near- mythological home computer, has gotten off to a rocky start in its battle with industry-titan IBM. With sales originally projected to be a million in the first quarter, Apple has sold only 35,000 of the user-friendly machines in the month since it’s been available to consumers.

content.text: DAN RATHER - CBS NEWS

dialogue: Apple Computers closed two of its factories today in the wake of disappointing sales for what was to be its new flagship computer, the Macintosh.

content.text: LOCAL NEWS - A COMPUTER EXPO

dialogue: Industry experts sight the lack of available software for the Mac as a reason for its failure to catch on with the public.

The insistence by Steve Jobs that it have what’s called end to end control, which is a way of saying that it’s not compatible with most outside software or hardware, is the Shakespearian flaw in a machine that had potential.

content.text: WALL STREET WEEK - PANEL DISCUSSION

dialogue: You know how many Macs were sold last month? Five hundred.

content.text: PETER JENNINGS - ABC NEWS

dialogue: Apple announced today that it will close down another one of its factories, this one in Dallas. For more on that we go to Barry Peterson and “Money Matters.”

content.text: DAN RATHER - CBS NEWS

dialogue: In a move that surprised some but not all on Wall Street and in the high tech corridors of Northern California, the board of directors of Apple Computer voted today to fire its cofounder, Steve Jobs.

content.text: “The Times They Are a-Changin’” continues--
TITLE:
San Francisco Opera House

The Opera House holds twice as many people as the Flint Auditorium did and the crowd to get in this morning seems three times as large as for the Mac launch. There are local news vans parked in front, photographers and press with credentials around their necks and of course the giant crowd waiting to get into the lobby, which is already jammed.
Huge banners hung from flagpoles tell us we’re here for the launch of NeXT and it’s first product--The Cube.
(V.O.) COME WRITERS AND CRITICS WHO PROPHESIZE WITH YOUR PEN AND KEEP YOUR EYES WIDE THE CHANCE WON’T COME AGAIN (MORE)
(V.O.) (CONT'D) AND DON’T SPEAK TOO SOON FOR THE WHEEL’S STILL IN SPIN AND THERE’S NO TELLIN’ WHO THAT IT’S NAMIN’ FOR THE LOSER NOW WILL BE LATER TO

dialogue: FOR THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN’

content.text: CUT TO:
STEVE’s alone on stage in a pool of light. His hair’s a little shorter now and his haircuts cost a few hundred bucks. But the real difference is a lighthearted air--an easy sense of humor.
On a beautifully lit table sits a black cube shrouded in a black cloth and next to it sits a vase of flowers. Slides change on the screen in back of Steve to accompany what he’s saying.

dialogue: Three thousand colleges and universities in the United States alone. Over 45 thousand departments, over 600 thousand faculty members, over 12 million students. Stanford’s annual budget’s 750 million dollars and growing. The University of Michigan- -over a billion dollars and growing. Ohio State, Cal, Colorado, UCLA, Georgia Tech--these are Fortune 500 companies disguised as George?

content.text: STEVE’s calling out to GEORGE COATES, the creative director of the presentation.

dialogue: The focus seems kind of sharp.
I think we want sharp focus.
It looks like I’m Steve the Magnificent.
You can’t see it from your angle.
I’ve seen it from every seat in the building and from too many of them does it look like I’m about to produce a silk scarf. Don’t take it personally, I’m just not a fan of the circus aesthetic.
We’re gonna have to go up and re- focus the instruments.

content.text: JOANNA’s walked on stage and is, of course, four years older.

dialogue: While we’re holding there are well- wishers in the VIP room.

content.text: They start heading off stage--

dialogue: I like the circus, I love the circus, but why does it still look like that?

Those performers are unbelievable. They have mastered incredibly hard albeit not very useful skills--I don’t know what the hell goes on in the Ukraine--and it should be presented in a more--I’m gonna revolutionize the circus.
Why are you in a good mood?
I’m always in a good mood.

content.text: STEVE doesn’t like hearing that and he takes his frustration out on the door as he pushes it open and they walk into--

dialogue: No more blue tents with yellow stars, no more costumes and transvestite make-up--a black stage, white light, and I’ll be perfectly honest I’m back and forth on clowns, you know why?
And Andy Hertzfeld. You have to see them, they want to pay their respects.
Not one of them has ever made me laugh.
You have to see them anyway.
I was talking about clowns, you unassimilated commie.
If they really wished me well they’d keep it to themselves.
I don’t think they do wish me well but I’m alright with that. I’m over Apple. I got over the Mac and Woz and Sculley the same way you get over your high school sweetheart. Build a new one.
You said you wouldn’t compete with them and you designed a computer specifically for the education market which they putatively own so I think it’s cool they’re here.
Still it was nice they came.
They’re not being magnanimous, they want it to look like an amicable divorce. History doesn’t remember Joe DiMaggio kindly for dumping Marilyn.

content.text: JOANNA makes a suppressed but loud sound while shutting her eyes and shaking her fists at God.

dialogue: I don’t know but I’m sure it can be traced back to you. You know I’m the one who has to explain you to people. $100,000 to Paul Rand for a corporate logo when we didn’t even know what our company made. A $650,000 mold for the Cube because God forbid the angles are 90.1 instead of 90.

content.text: STEVE
of 90. That box could be on display at the Guggenheim and you’re forgetting about the number of coats of paint.

dialogue: On the Cube or the factory? As if customers are out there thinking, “You know I’d buy that thing except I’m not sure I like the color of the walls at their plant in Fort Worth.”
You’re very funny for someone with no imagination.
Don’t give them a reason to say to the press you have a chip on your shoulder, will you do that for me?
I don’t have a chip on my shoulder.
Okay, but don’t give them a reason to say you do.
They’re gonna call me back in a minute to look at the light.
Get one out of the way.
No questions from the press after.
Until I have better answers. No press avail. Somebody asks where I am, you just saw me and I’ll be right back.
How long do you think that’s going to work?
I don’t know, how good are you at your job?
Tell me what I don’t know. I mean it, tell me.

content.text: JOANNA’s starting to try to figure something out...

dialogue: Okay. Who do you want first?
Bring me the face of Steve Wozniak.

content.text: STEVE walks into--
--where he walks to a small refrigerator and takes out a bottle of water. He turns around and--
--reacts to the sight of LISA, now nine years old, who he clearly didn’t know was in the room.
LISA is studiously measuring the sides of the NeXT Computer, the black cube, with a plastic ruler. She has a Sony Walkman on her waist with the headphones around her neck.

dialogue: I thought you went to school?
You were supposed to go to school an hour ago, I thought you left.

I didn’t wake up my mom on time this morning. It’s happened before too. I wake up with the alarm and then I get dressed and eat breakfast but then sometimes I forget to see what time it is after that.
Why doesn’t your mom just set her own alarm clock?

content.text: STEVE hates hearing this but doesn’t want to get into it.

dialogue: Well I don’t understand what that has to do with why you’re still-- where’s your mother?
She went to find a pay phone.

content.text: LISA raises her hand.

dialogue: You don’t have to raise your hand.
You said it was off by a little.

content.text: STEVE looks at her a second and then goes to the door and pops his head out, looking for help--

dialogue: Exactly a foot on all four sides.
There are six sides but you’re not supposed to be here right now.
We know if four sides are equal to each other the other two are equal as well.
The top, bottom, right and left are about a millimeter shorter than the front and back.
Lisa, I’m kind of an expert in design and that’s a 20 cent ruler, you think there’s a chance it could be off?

content.text: LISA thinks about it a moment...

dialogue: If I had another ruler I could measure the ruler but I really doubt
--comes back, you have to go to school.
Did you hear what I just said?
‘Cause sometimes it seems like you just keep saying what you want without listening.

content.text: There’s a silence for a moment...
Another uncomfortable silence...

dialogue: Why isn’t it a perfect cube?
It’s an optical anomaly. To the human eye a perfect cube doesn’t look like a cube so we made it roughly a millimeter shorter than a foot on two sides.
You’ve asked me that before too, I don’t know why you do that.

content.text: LISA doesn’t really know what to say...because she’s nine.

dialogue: It’s an exception, something that doesn’t fit a pattern.

content.text: There’s a knock on the door--

dialogue: You have to go to school.

content.text: JOANNA opens the door and she and WOZ enter--

dialogue: I think you two have met.
So do you, so do you.
And they’re telling me George is ready for you to look at the focus.
I’m your dad’s friend, Steve Wozniak.
I apologize, I don’t remember you.

content.text: WOZ heads out the door--
STEVE joins WOZ out in--
--where they make their way to the stage.

dialogue: You know this is the first time ever we haven’t played for the same team. It’s like you’re releasing your first solo album. I appreciate your inviting me to the launch.
I just want to wipe the slate clean.
That’s exactly what I want. That’s why I came backstage. I want you to know I’ll be out there with you.
Any chance I could get you to go out there instead of me?
I’m clumsy at this. I guess--
They were published. You knew you were talking to a reporter from Fortune, right? You weren’t tricked?
Look, I don’t even remember exactly what I said. I know it was--
“Steve can be an insulting and hurtful guy.”
“I look forward to a great product and I wish him success--
“--but his integrity I cannot trust.” Wait here a second.

content.text: They’re backstage now and STEVE walks onto the stage where there’s a new pool of light waiting for him. We stay on WOZ backstage for a moment, who now understands that Steve’s version of wiping the slate clean and his are two different things.
GEORGE COATES calls from out in the house--
STEVE looks at the floor, at the edges of the pool of light--

dialogue: Good. Where do you want to pick it up?
A word that’s sometimes used to describe me--
Hold please, they’re not cued up.
We’ve got about 10 minutes before we have to clear the house.
I doubt we’re starting on time.
We still have to get through--
We make computers, we’re--I’ve had this conversation before--we’re starting on time.

content.text: The giant screen behind Steve is showing the NeXT desktop as STEVE demonstrates the thesaurus feature.

dialogue: A word that’s sometimes used to describe me is “mercurial.”
Let’s look at the dictionary definitions.
“Of or relating to or born under the planet Mercury.”
I think the third one is what they mean.

content.text: STEVE glances offstage where he sees that LISA is now watching a few feet from WOZ.

dialogue: If we scroll down the thesaurus, though, we see the antonym is “saturnine.” By simply double- clicking on it we immediately look that up in the dictionary and here it is: “Cold and steady in moods. Slow to act or change. Of a gloomy or surly disposition.”
So I don’t think “mercurial” is so bad after all.

content.text: STEVE walks to the wings--

dialogue: It’s against the law for you not to be in school.
My mom said I could watch.

content.text: STEVE leads LISA and WOZ back into--

dialogue: Why did mercurial end up not being a bad word?
Do you remember asking me that the night before last when you were having dinner at my house?
The word that was the opposite of mercurial was bad, which meant mercurial was good.
I think you do get it.
‘Cause we also talked about it when you came to the rehearsal last week.
I meant why aren’t they straight on other things?
Why does it feel like you’re working me?
Woz? Why aren’t the angles straight on other things?

When the manufacturers make things with 90 degree angles, they cheat the angle a little bit--89, 91--so that it’s easier to get the object out of the mold. Like getting a cake out of a pan. But on your dad’s new computer he insisted the angles be exactly 90 degrees.
Some people don’t mean cool when they use that word.

content.text: STEVE opens the door to --
--where CHRISANN is waiting.

dialogue: I thought you guys left an hour ago.
She wants to watch her father’s presentation.
Wait in here, I’ll be right back.

content.text: STEVE closes the door behind her and stands alone in the hall with WOZ--

dialogue: Were you pressured to do it?

content.text: STEVE looks around...then WOZ follows him through a double- door marked “Authorized Personnel Only” and into--
Empty chairs and empty music stands are arranged in a semi- circle facing an empty conductor’s podium.
STEVE looks around at it for a moment...WOZ doesn’t really know what they’re doing there. STEVE begins walking around slowly...

dialogue: Check it out. It’s the orchestra pit for the San Francisco Opera.
Was I pressured to do it?
I once met Seiji Ozawa at Tanglewood. Thunderous conductor. Ungodly artfulness and nuance. And I asked him what exactly a conductor does that a metronome can’t do. Surprisingly--
--he didn’t beat the shit out of you?
That’s right. No, he said, “The musicians play their instruments. I play the orchestra.”
That feels like something that sounds good but doesn’t mean anything.
Markkula, Sculley, did they ask you to slag me off in the press?
But they asked you to talk.
Apple was under siege, you’d just left the company, somebody had to talk to the press.
I’m right here, Woz, the company left me.
I begged you, I begged you. The Apple II accounted for 70% of revenue, what’d you think was gonna happen? You didn’t care enough about the Apple II or the Lisa.
Let’s be really clear, I didn’t care at all about the Apple II or the Lisa.
I wasn’t pressured to do it. What I said to the press was an honest if tempered reflection of what I believed.
What the fuck is on your wrist?
Everyone’s going to be wearing this in 10 years. It’s a Nixie Watch made using Nixie tubes.

content.text: WOZ is showing STEVE his watch. It’s a chunky thing that gives a large digital read-out of the time. The thing is that the numbers look exactly like the kind of numbers that are on a time-bomb when it counts down in the movies.

dialogue: This is actually 40-year-old technology--cold cathode tubes and they’re running on 140 volts.
I tilt my wrist 45 degrees and it’s right there--hours and minutes--the way our minds work.
Do me a favor--set the watch ahead like you’re on a plane and changed time zones.

content.text: WOZ unscrews the face of the watch, the MacGyver-bomb numbers look even worse as WOZ starts to press tiny buttons with the tip of his pen.

dialogue: Excuse me, flight attendant? The man next to me would appear to be detonating a bomb.

content.text: WOZ stops...

dialogue: You think it looks like a bomb?
Even right now I’m not a hundred percent sure it isn’t.
Maybe once people get used to--

content.text: They sit in silence a moment...

dialogue: I was angry. You were saying things about the Apple II and the way you were treating the
Woz--you get a free pass for life, okay?
I’ve gotta get back onstage, we’ve got like two minutes of rehearsal time left.

content.text: STEVE heads for the door but he’s stopped by--

dialogue: Do you understand how condescending that just was? Maybe you
I don’t want to see you dragged off an airplane in plastic handcuffs, how is that--
I get a free pass for life? From you? You’re the one who gives out the passes?! You give ‘em to me?!!
You’re gonna have a stroke, li’l buddy.
What did you do?! What did you do?! Why has Lisa not heard of me?
Shit, man, how many fourth-graders have heard of you?

You can’t write code. You’re not an engineer, you’re not a designer, you can’t put a hammer to a nail. I built the circuit board, the graphical interface was stolen from Xerox PARC, Jeff Raskin was the leader of the Mac team before you threw him off his own project... everything! Somebody else designed the box! So how come 10 times in a day I read Steve Jobs is a genius? What do you do?
I play the orchestra. And you’re a good musician.
You sit right there. You’re the best in your row.
I came here to clear the air. You know why I came here?

I came here ‘cause you’re gonna get killed. Your computer is going to fail. You had a college and university advisory board telling you they need a powerful workstation for 2 to 3 thousand, you’ve priced NeXT at 6500, which doesn’t include the optional three thousand-dollar hard drive which people will discover isn’t optional because the optical disk is too weak to do anything and the twenty five hundred dollar laser printer brings the total to twelve-thousand dollars and in the entire world, you are the only person who cares that it’s housed in a perfect cube. You’re gonna get killed and I came here to stand next to you while that happens because that’s what friends do, that’s what men do, I don’t need your pass. We go back so don’t talk to me like I’m other people. I’m the only one who knows that this guy here is someone you invented. I’m standing by you ‘cause that perfect cube that does nothing is about to be the single biggest failure in the history of personal computing.

content.text: STEVE wants to tear into WOZ and he considers it for a quick moment but instead of doing that he says this...

dialogue: Tell me something else I don’t know.

content.text: STEVE opens the door and walks out into--
JOANNA’s waiting.

dialogue: We’re out of time. They’ve got to mop the stage and open the house.

content.text: STEVE looks at her...

dialogue: If it crashes it crashes, right?
It’s a good slogan. “NeXT: If it Crashes it Crashes.”
I’m not just talking about the demo. Steve? If it tanks we don’t swallow cyanide, we go back to the drawing board.
No more drawing boards. You invent the Edsel twice and you don’t get anymore drawing boards. So let’s not--
Tell me what the plan is. You have to tell me the plan because I don’t know. You’re walking around like you’ve got can’t-lose cards.
The plan will reveal itself to you when you’re ready to see it.
Will I have to drop acid?
Have I ever let you down?
Joanna, there is a plan. But I don’t want to put you in a position where you’re lying to people.

content.text: JOANNA considers this a moment...

dialogue: (can recompile and try to give us a fighting)
--are we gonna have this con--we’re not starting late. Ever. We’re not ever starting late.
But where do you come down on starting late?

content.text: STEVE takes a moment...

dialogue: Lisa’s been doing this thing where she asks me about stuff I’ve already told her. She asks me questions and I know she already knows the answers. What’s that about?

Kids do that when they’re scared one of their parents is in a bad mood. They try to get you talking about something you like. It’s very common and can be treated by talking to her about things she likes.
Do have any training or experience in this field?

content.text: STEVE heads down the hall a little, opens the door and walks into--
--where CHRISANN is waiting.

dialogue: An hour ago you said you were taking her to school.
She begged me to let her stay. There are fathers who would so love--

It is wrong, okay? It is morally wrong, it is parentally wrong, it is wrong for you to use Lisa as a way of getting money from me. She will know if she doesn’t already that that is your primary use for her and
(she will hate you for it for the rest of your life)
She will see, if she doesn’t already, that her mother is a woman who stands up to men.
By not letting myself be imprisoned and degraded by them.
Imprisoned? I can’t get rid of you!
I need a doctor and I need a dentist.
I dropped out of college after a semester but okay, let’s have a look.
You will support your daughter and her mother.
Did you pay someone fifteen hundred dollars to bless your house?
Did you hear what I said?
I don’t remember how much it was, Steve.
They don’t do it for free.
They don’t, they charge fifteen- hundred dollars.
How I spend--fuck, you know, I’m
Were you about to say, “How I spend my money is none of your business?”
I have a sinus infection and I need to see a dentist too.
So you can see how your blessing budget could have been better spent.
Look at me. You know who I am, right?
And you know I know people.
Look at me. And you know the people I know, they know people.
If I ever hear again that you’ve thrown a cereal bowl at Lisa’s head--
--my private line is gonna ring and a voice on the other end is gonna say, “We’re all set.” And that’s how I’ll learn that you’re dead.
Are you cra--I threw the bowl on the floor! I didn’t throw it at her head, she wasn’t even in the room! She was nowhere near--I threw it on the floor!
She’s a little girl, you’re scaring her. I’m a grown man, you’re scaring me. Taking out the garbage is a chore, clearing the table is a chore, waking you up in the morning is just fuckin’ creepy.
Please teach me more about being a parent. It means--
It means so much coming from someone who won’t admit he is one.
We’re all set. Stop screaming at Lisa.
--and one day she’s going to thank me for it.
I never threw anything at her head. I never--I never would.
Things don’t become so because you say so.
There’ll be more money in your account by the end of business.

content.text: STEVE opens the door and walks out into--
--where JOANNA’s still waiting.

dialogue: Hertzfeld. He’s playing with Avie Tevanian and the computer backstage.

content.text: JOEL PFORZHEIMER, the reporter we met briefly in the first act, runs and catches up with STEVE and JOANNA.
STEVE turns to see him coming but keeps walking with JOANNA--

dialogue: Can he do it later, Joel, we go in 8 minutes.
Can I just get a quick reaction to the press this morning?
The size of it, the volume.
I was hoping for a quote from Steve.

I’ll tell you on background that I’ve never seen anything like it in the tech industry. I called the Wall Street Journal to take out a full page ad for today and you know what their sales guy said? “Why bother? It’d be like notifying Macy’s that tomorrow is Christmas.”
You saw the Stewart Alsop newsletter?
I’m sorry, Joanna, I need to get Steve on the record.
The headline was “Dear NeXT: When Can I Get My Machine?”
We’ll announce the ship date in the next 8-10 weeks.
Alsop’s not talking about the ship date, he wants to know when he can get one to play with.
We have a lot of respect for Stewart Alsop and we want to get a machine into his hands so he can tell his subscribers about it.
A couple of days, a week? Off the record.
He’ll get it when it’s finished.

content.text: JOEL stops walking. STEVE and JOANNA stop too.

dialogue: I’ve been watching you rehearse the demo for three weeks.
We’re off the record and Joel’s always been good at understanding nuance.
I guess in layman’s terms you’d have to say we don’t have an OS.
Well the OS is what runs the computer. In fact it sort of is the computer.
How has it been running, how is it gonna run this morning? What do you mean you don’t have an OS?

content.text: They walk into--
ANDY HERTZFELD is huddled over the shoulder of AVIE TEVANIAN and some ENGINEERS who are busy with last minute checks.

dialogue: Avie Tevanian is our chief software designer and he wrote a demo program. It’s like this, we built a great car, we haven’t built the engine, so we put a golf cart battery in there to make it go for a little bit. All this computer knows how to do right now is demonstrate itself.
You’re telling me the only thing you’ve built is a black cube?
Yeah, but isn’t it the coolest black cube you’ve ever seen?
Is this--we’re off the record--is this a strategy or a problem because if it’s a problem--

content.text: STEVE interrupts this and points to ANDY--

dialogue: Do not share proprietary knowledge with that man.

content.text: STEVE’s walking over to ANDY and AVIE, who are busy on the computer.

dialogue: I don’t understand it either and my name’s on the patents.
Email’s not just for tech specialists anymore. Well it is, but it won’t be.
And I assume an email sent on a NeXT computer can only be received by a NeXT computer?
The new trash can is wrong. I want to tell you I appreciate all the hours you put into it but I can’t because of how terrible it is.
We’ll go back to the other one.
And why are we still giving three options on the clock?
How many options do you want to give?
Can I talk to you a second?

content.text: ANDY leads STEVE away to talk to him privately--

dialogue: Look, man, Avie’s been recompiling but he says there may be some glitches this morning.
If all there are are some glitches it’ll be a triumph of a miraculous magnitude. Why are you translating for Avie?
I didn’t want him to find out the hard way your position on glitches in a demo but it sounds like you’ve mellowed.
I’ve been growing, Andy, I’ve been learning to love myself.
I wouldn’t have ever dreamed that was a problem.
Fantastic burn. You need to go to your seat.
And how ‘bout Lisa? Getting into a school for gifted kids?
Yeah, she was tested and it turns out she can fly.

content.text: ANDY wants STEVE to treat this like it’s a big deal.

dialogue: I know it’s a big deal. That’s why I built the school a building.
I’m sure that’s not why she got in.
Can I show you something funny from MacWorld?
I can’t think of anything I have to do right now.

content.text: JOANNA comes over--ANDY’s taken a folded-up page from a magazine out of his pocket.

dialogue: Andy, he’s only got a few minutes.
It’s Guy Kawasaki writing in MacWorld, you’re gonna like this.
Can we all enjoy it later?

He wrote a parody press release about Apple buying NeXT for your OS. He imagines a near-future where Apple needs your OS and has to buy NeXT and you come back as CEO. He has Gates saying there would now be more innovations from Jobs that Microsoft could copy. You can read it later.
She would have gotten in without you donating a building.
She’s a very bright girl, Steve.
Still, it was something to talk about in the interview.

content.text: ANDY exits backstage to head out into the house...

dialogue: Give it to me, I’ll throw it out for you.
I’m gonna hang on to it.

content.text: STEVE folds the article and puts it in his pocket. JOANNA stares at him, trying to puzzle through what’s happening...
But STEVE’s seen something up in the lighting grid. She’s sitting in her coat and scarf and listening to music on her Walkman.
STEVE heads up the metal stairs and onto--
LISA sees her father and smiles as he walks toward her.
She either can’t hear him or is pretending she can’t.

dialogue: It’s dangerous up here, that’s why I make other people do it.

content.text: LISA points to her headphones. STEVE kneels down and pushes the headphones down around her neck.

dialogue: Who are you hiding from, me or your mom?

content.text: LISA gets up and follows her father to the stairs--

dialogue: I’m listening to two versions of the same song. And then when I get to the end I rewind and listen to them again. It’s the same song but the versions are different.

content.text: STEVE holds a moment...then sees an opening.

dialogue: Okay, so it’s a really old song and it’s called “Both Sides Now.”

content.text: That went alright so STEVE tries it again.

dialogue: It’s about--there are three verses. Clouds, love and life. And the person singing is singing that they used to think of, that they used to think about, you know--
--right, one way, yeah, but now they look at them another way and now they’re, you know, they’ve...
--they’ve come to the conclusion that they really don’t know clouds, love or life at all?
Yeah Joni Mitchell, ‘cause it’s not a really old song unless I’m a really old guy. You have to go to school now.

content.text: They’ve come down the metal stairs and land--

dialogue: You want me to tell you the difference between the two versions?
The first version is the kind of thing you’d call girlish.
I didn’t mean that I want to know the difference right now, I meant you have to go to school right now.
You are truant, you’re committing a crime.
I’m not gonna miss anything important.
I read ahead. The Pilgrims make it to the New World.

content.text: JOANNA opens the door and steps into the backstage area from the corridor--

dialogue: Yeah you skipped over a couple of centuries.

content.text: STEVE and LISA are quiet for a moment...we HEAR the sound of the giant sold-out house.

dialogue: Can I make my case for staying?

content.text: STEVE walks LISA out into--
--where CHRISANN is waiting.

dialogue: Come on. Your dad doesn’t want us to stay.
Hey that’s not true, that’s not--

content.text: STEVE gives CHRISANN a look that says “What the hell?”--

dialogue: You have to be in school is all.
I’m committing a crime right now, I don’t want to get in trouble.
You’re not in trouble, I was kidding.

content.text: STEVE’s feeling the pull of not really wanting her to go.

dialogue: Hey what was the second version? You said the first version was girlish, what was the second version?
I can’t really think of the word.
Okay, well have a good day at
Like wishing you could go back and do things over again.
You’re too young to be regretful.
Not me, the person singing the song.

content.text: She puts her arms around her father’s waist and hugs him--
CHRISANN and LISA head off as STEVE stands there with JOANNA looking on. STEVE turns and looks at JOANNA and she looks at a spot on the floor and shakes her head.
STEVE’s thinking about a lot of things but all that comes out of his mouth is--

dialogue: Six minutes. You want to see Sculley?
It sounded exactly like a question to me. I’ll see him after.

content.text: Steve walks down the corridor alone.
Steve surveys the crowd for a moment then walks out into--
--Steve stops when he hears the voice of John Sculley

dialogue: You know all those times I told you you needed security? Here’s why.

content.text: STEVE’s looking at SCULLEY. SCULLEY’s a sworn enemy now but STEVE’s not going to show him that. He has bigger plans.

dialogue: I don’t know how it is I’ve gotten older and you haven’t. Some deal with the devil I was never offered.
So you know what I’ve been thinking for the last four years?
As it turns out I’ve never known what you were thinking.
No newborn baby has control, do you know what I’m talking about? In ‘84, before the Mac launch, you said--
You said that being adopted meant you didn’t have control.
We’re starting in a minute so--
Why do people think I fired you?
It’s fine, John, it’s all behind us.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

It’s a beautiful house but it’s almost entirely unfurnished. There’s a very nice floor lamp, a framed photograph of Einstein on the wall...and that’s about it. Except for a Mac that sits in the middle of the floor.
The DOORBELL RINGS--STEVE looks at the door--
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Don’t play stupid, you can’t pull it off.
You came here to ask me--

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:
STEVE’S FOYER - NIGHT
STEVE opens the door and SCULLEY is standing there.
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: I haven’t seen or spoken to you in three years.
Why do people think I fired you?
Just confirm something for me, okay? You liked the ad, right?

content.text: STEVE (CONT'D)
it?
QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: When are you gonna get furniture?
It is, you buy a couch and take it from there.
I’ve been thinking a lot about couches. What do we use them for?
I’d be really surprised if you came here to talk about interior decorating.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: I liked the ad very much.
You know I did, now please answer my question.
You’re lying, son of a bitch, you tried to kill it.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: It’s time to take a hard look at the Mac.
It’s past time. It’s overpriced, we need to drop it to nineteen ninety- five. We need to double the marketing budget, put more bodies on an internal hard drive and invest in FileServer.
Where would that money come from?
It would come from finally getting rid of the Apple II.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Where the hell did you get the idea I tried
I understood the board’s concerns but I certainly did not
The board’s concern that we didn’t show the product.
What other things? You said among other things.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: The Apple II is the only thing making money.
That’s because we keep selling it.
I can’t diagram that logic but--
We keep making it so people keep-- the Mac needs to sell for $1995.

There is no market research telling us the Mac is failing because it’s overpriced. It’s telling us that people don’t like it because they think it doesn’t DO anything, it’s closed end to end. We didn’t know it wasn’t what people wanted but it isn’t, they want slots, they want choices, they want options. The way we buy stereos, mix and match components.
John, listen to me. Whoever said the customer is always right was, I promise you, a customer.
My job is to make a recommendation to the board.
Recommend that we drop the price, double the marketing--
Well what are you gonna do, recommend that we kill the Mac?

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Among other things, it was set in a dystopian galaxy, it took place on a planet where we don’t live, it was dark and the opposite of our brand. And we didn’t show the product. People talked about the ad but most of them didn’t know what we were selling.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: Just now. An hour ago. I’m coming from Markkula’s house.
What do you want the headache for? Moving money around, figuring out what--invent something new. I’ll give you a team, you can sit in Maui, the resorts come with couches.
Wait a minute--are you saying you recommended terminating the Mac or you recommended taking me off the Mac team?

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: They thought it was--it had skinheads in it but that’s
The ad didn’t have anything to do with fucking skinheads! We used them as fucking extras! Nobody even knows they were skinheads!
You invented lifestyle advertising and “our brand” was my brand.

We showed a lot of happy people drinking Pepsi, we didn’t say the world was gonna come to an end if you bought a Dr. Pepper. And we showed the product! We showed it being opened, we showed it being poured, being consumed--
You think the secret to your success was not assuming people knew what they were supposed to do with a can of soda?
I didn’t kill the ad, Steve! I’m the only reason it made it on the air!

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: If we drop the price and
Steve! You can’t drop the price and double a budget! The only way to do that is to take money out of the Apple II and--
The Apple II should embarrass you. It embarrasses me. If you had any pride at all--
It doesn’t embarrass the shareholders, Steve,
I don’t give a shit about--the shareholders are your problem, that’s why I hired you, so I don’t ever have to hear about--
The shareholders are my problem and the board represents the shareholders. That’s how it works.
You’re doing both. You’re moving me off the Mac and phasing it out.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Woz and I offered to put up our own money and you’re the only reason the ad was on the air?

We’d bought three spots in the Super Bowl--two 30’s and a 60--for six-hundred thousand and after we screened it the board wanted that money back and they asked me to sell off the spots. Chiat/Day sold off the two 30’s but not the 60 and I let it be known to Lee Clow that if he didn’t try very hard to sell the last spot I wouldn’t be unhappy. And that’s how the ad got on the air. Maybe remember that the next time someone tells you you were brilliant to only run the ad once.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: You’re really talking about killing the Mac.
I’m euthanizing the Mac, it’s a mercy killing.
I’m gonna take this to the board myself.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: You sure it wasn’t Lee Clow who dragged his feet selling the 60?
At my direction, Steve, you think he would have done that on his own?! Taken it on himself?!
Yes, I think he would have done what it took to save it from you!
I was the only thing protecting it!
You didn’t want the ad because you were trying to kill the Mac two months before it launched!

content.text: And now it’s like two boxers unclench after a furious series of punches, move apart and take a breath...

dialogue: Can I mention something to you? I have no earthly idea why you’re here.
The story...of why and how you left Apple...which is quickly becoming mythologized...isn’t true.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: Don’t press it with the board, Steve. I’m imploring you.
They believe you’re no longer necessary to this company.

content.text: We stay with STEVE being silent for a long moment before we--
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: I get hate mail. Death threats.
I get death threats. My kids get taunted. Why do people think I fired you?
Joanna’s gonna call my name in a second.
Yeah, I’ll be just a second.
I gave you your day in court.
I gave the board a clear choice. I said do you want to invest in the Apple II or the Mac and they chose the Apple II--
The same people who wanted to dump the Super Bowl spot--
--and then I got on a plane to China.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

scene_info.location: CATHAY PACIFIC AIRLINES FIRST CLASS LOUNGE

content.text: RAIN BEATS AGAINST THE WINDOW as we see SCULLEY sitting at the bar. A CONCIERGE steps up--
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Or I almost got on but I got a call in the lounge.
It matters to me. Who made the call?

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

scene_info.location: CATHAY PACIFIC AIRLINES FIRST CLASS LOUNGE

content.text: SCULLEY is on the phone at the desk, listening to the voice at the other end.

dialogue: If you get on that plane you’ll have lost your job by the time you land. He’s starting a civil war.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: I left my bags on the plane--my shit’s still somewhere in Beijing-- I took a car back to Cupertino in the middle of the fucking--

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:
RAIN BEATS AGAINST THE OFFICE WINDOWS as SCULLEY speaks on the phone--

dialogue: I know what time it is, I need a quorum here in one hour. And I want Steve here too.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: You took me off the Mac and it was bad business. The quorum call was a homicide.
Right there is the part that’s bullshit, my friend, it was a suicide, because you knew your cards and I showed you mine, I showed you mine and you did it anyway.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:
CHRISANN is arguing with STEVE while six-year-old LISA has her face buried in her homework at the kitchen table. Rain is beating against the windows.

dialogue: Everything’s about her all of a sudden. All the time. All she does is come home and do homework and study and ask to see you. Everything’s about her. Everything’s about you. And I’m the maid.
I don’t think you’re the maid and I guarantee you’re the only parent in America who’s complaining about her kid spending too much time studying.

content.text: The DOORBELL RINGS--

dialogue: Who comes over to your house this late?

content.text: CHRISANN exits the kitchen to get the door. STEVE looks at LISA...

dialogue: When you finish with that you should get ready for bed, okay?

content.text: What? STEVE’s stunned by the question that was heartbreakingly sincere and simple and came out of nowhere...
He’s about to say something--anything--when CHRISANN comes back in with ANDY HERTZFELD.

dialogue: I tried your house first. Sculley’s called an emergency meeting of the board.

content.text: STEVE’s still thinking about what LISA just asked--

dialogue: He’s supposed to be on his way to China.

content.text: ANDY shakes his head “no”--

dialogue: I have to go to--she should get ready for bed when she’s done with this.
I’m sorry. Lees?...I have to go.

content.text: STEVE and ANDY head out as we--
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: What’d you think I was gonna do? I’m okay losing but I’m not gonna forfeit.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:
Rain is beating against the windows. BOARD MEMBERS are there in various different dress--some from an evening out. STEVE stands to the side while SCULLEY addresses the board --

dialogue: We’re losing market share and the Mac is losing money. Our only hope is the Apple II which is stagnating because of it’s soon-to-be-obsolete DOS. Users are already rigging their machines to run with the CP/M operating system that’s been built to run on Intel. I can’t put it more simply than this--we need to put our resources into updating the Apple II.
By taking resources from the Mac.
I’m the evidence! I am the world’s leading expert on the Mac, John, what’s your resume?!

You’re issuing contradictory instructions, you’re insubordinate, you make people miserable, our top engineers are fleeing to Sun, Dell, HP--Wall Street doesn’t know who’s driving the bus, we’ve lost hundreds of millions in value and I’m the CEO of Apple, Steve, that’s my resume!
