But before that you sold carbonated sugar water, right? I sat in a fuckin’ garage with Wozniak and invented the future because artists lead and hacks ask for a show of hands.

content.text: The board is tense...even a little bit scared...except SCULLEY, who just takes a breath, takes a beat and says--

dialogue: Alright, well...this guy’s outta control. I’m perfectly willing to hand in my resignation tonight. But if you want me to stay you can’t have Steve. He’ll have to sever any connection to Apple. Settle him out. He can keep a share of stock so he gets our newsletter.
I’m dead serious, I’d like the secretary to call for a vote.

content.text: The BOARD MEMBERS look at STEVE, who leans against the wall...
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: You’ve done an outstanding job over the years of cultivating the press and by that I mean manipulating it ‘cause none of them, and none of their editors, and none of the editors’ publishers, to this day, have any idea that you forced it. That you forced the board even after I told you exactly what they’d do. Which is exactly what they did. Unanimously.

I don’t have any trouble remembering that, John, because of it being the worst night of my life and I forced a vote because I believed I was right, I still believe I’m right...and I’m right. I bled that night and I don’t bleed. But time’s done its thing and I really haven’t thought about it in a while. I absolutely understand why you’re upset and I want people to know the truth too.

content.text: SCULLEY looks at STEVE...he’s lying.

dialogue: You’re gonna end me, aren’t you.

content.text: STEVE smiles...

dialogue: You’re being ridiculous. I’m gonna sit center court and watch you do it yourself. Then I’m gonna order a nice meal with a ‘55 Margaux and sign some autographs.

You want my help, Pepsi Generation? Don’t send Woz out to slap me around in the press. Anybody else. You, Markkula, Arthur Rock, anyone but Rainman. Don’t manipulate him like that. Whatever you may think I’m always gonna protect him.
That’s what men do. I can’t start late.

content.text: STEVE exits out into--
--where JOANNA’s waiting. They walk down the corridor in silence for a few moments before--

dialogue: I don’t think there was any way to detect a chip on my shoulder.
Did you know back at Bandley, the Mac team gave an award every year to the person who could stand up to you?
I won three years in a row.

content.text: They walk through a door and are--
--where JOANNA pushes STEVE up against the closest wall.
JOANNA reaches into his pocket and pulls out the folded MacWorld article.

dialogue: This--Guy Kawasaki in MacWorld--he accidentally got it right, didn’t he? You’ve been dragging your feet on the NeXT OS until you can figure out what Apple’s gonna need.

content.text: Again we can HEAR the rock concert energy of the audience waiting for Steve...

dialogue: Even if that were true it doesn’t sound diabolical to me.

content.text: STEVE nods to the STAGE MANAGER--
We HEAR the audience CHEER.
We also HEAR a synthesizer introduction to a piece of music that will crash in in just a moment--

dialogue: I’m your closest confidant, your best friend, your thing--what do you call it--work wife. This whole time, the last three years--
--when did you change your mind and start building the Steve Jobs Revenge Machine?
You remember Skylab? It was an unmanned satellite NASA sent up in the early ‘70s on an eight year data gathering mission.

The thing is, when they sent it up they didn’t know yet how they were gonna get it back but they felt like they were close enough that in the eight years it was gonna be up there they’d figure it out. They didn’t. So after eight years it lost its orbit and came crashing down in a thousand-mile swath across the Indian Ocean. Little to the left, little to the right and somebody coulda gotten hurt.

I really wanted to build a computer for colleges. The technology just didn’t catch up as fast as I needed it to. And you know we’re outta money. But then Apple stopped innovating and I saw something better. Joanna, I know schools aren’t gonna buy a $13,000 dictionary with good speakers, you know I know that. But Apple will ‘cause Avie Tevanian is gonna build exactly the OS they need. And they’re gonna have to buy me too. For half a billion dollars in stock and end-to-end control on every product.

content.text: STEVE gives a nod to the STAGE MANAGER--
A WOMAN with a script open on a music stand speaks into a microphone--
HARD CUT TO:
BLACK
--and the synthesizer intro becomes “For Unto Us a Child is Born,” the beautiful choral piece from Handel’s “Messiah,” only it’s a contemporary version being sung semi-acappella by The Roches.
With “For Unto Us a Child is Born” as the score we go through a series of scenes.
ABC NEWS - PETER JENNINGS

dialogue: More than a year after it was first unveiled to industry insiders, the NeXT Computer is now available in retail stores. For more we go to ABC News Senior Technology Correspondent Martin Rath.

content.text: The song continues...
WALL STREET WEEK - PANEL

dialogue: And meanwhile Apple is continuing to lose market share with no new innovations in the pipeline except the Newton, which is a pet project of CEO John Sculley.

content.text: CNBC - PANEL

dialogue: So much for the black cube. NeXT just sold its factory to Canon and laid off half its employees.

content.text: CBS - DAN RATHER

dialogue: The former tech giant, Apple, and for more on that--

content.text: WALL STREET WEEK - PANEL

dialogue: With an operating system that can’t compete with Windows and no new innovations in the pipeline except Newton, a product no one seems excited about except John Sculley--

content.text: MONEY MATTERS - PANEL

dialogue: Apple stock’s fallen from $70 a share when Steve Jobs was the heartbeat of the company to $14 today and no one thinks the Newton is gonna turn it around.

content.text: The song continues...
ABC NEWS - MARTIN RATH

dialogue: Gil Amelio, formerly of National Semiconductor was installed as the new CEO of Apple today and he’s inherited a sinking ship.

content.text: CNBC - PANEL

dialogue: Gil Amelio’s gonna discover that Copland’s a bust. When that happens he’ll have to mollify Wall Street and publicly promise to find an alternative.

content.text: MONEY MATTERS

dialogue: Under the direction of Steve Jobs, NeXT’s chief software designer, Avie Tevanian, has developed an object-oriented, UNIX-like operating system that’s caught the attention of big players in Silicon Valley--

content.text: CNBC - PANEL
WALL STREET WEEK - PANEL
CBS NEWS - DAN RATHER

dialogue: With a buzz reserved for rock stars, Steve Jobs--

content.text: ABC NEWS - PETER JENNINGS
CNBC - ANCHOR

dialogue: Buy Apple stock. Buy it now. Sell the kids, buy the stock.

content.text: WALL STREET WEEK - PANEL

dialogue: Steve Jobs is returning to Apple.

content.text: CBS NEWS - DAN RATHER

dialogue: Take the “interim” off his title, Steve Jobs is now the CEO of the company he founded in his garage and fans of Apple are counting the days until his first new product.

content.text: “For Unto Us a Child is Born” continues as we--
CUT TO:
A giant crowd waits outside to be let in. The place is festooned with banners with the now-famous “Think Different” campaign.
In the audience we see some familiar faces among the dozens of APPLE STAFFERS working the rehearsal. JOANNA, WOZ, ANDY HERTZFELD and the reporter JOEL PFORZHEIMER is there too.
Everyone is 10 years older than the last time we saw them.

dialogue: This thing has 100MB Ethernet as standard, and why? Because we’re seeing these high speed networks in homes now. Ten percent of the homes in Silicon Valley now have Class Five wiring in them.

content.text: TITLE:
Davies Symphony Hall

STEVE’s on stage in front of a giant screen showing changing slides that reflect whatever he’s mentioning at the moment. He’s dressed in dark jeans, a white shirt buttoned up to the neck and a black sport jacket. On a small table, which is in the dark at the moment, sits a computer under a dark silk sheet.
STEVE’s loose and having a good time with the hundred or so employees in the audience who are revved up for the big morning.

dialogue: A fast modem and also a 4MB IrDA built in. You wanna beam your digital photographs from your digital camera? It’s built in to every product.
Check it out--no notes, no note cards--ready?
(back to it and faster now to play with the employees in the house)

We’re going to the new generation of IO--12Mb USB, two ports--we’re leaving the old Apple IO behind. Stereo Surround Sound built in to every product, a great keyboard and the coolest mouse you’ve ever seen. This time we used real mice.
We’re opening the house in 10 minutes, Steven, you want to stop horsing around?
Bless my eyes, that’s Steve Wozniak sitting out there.

content.text: The APPLE employees give him a cheer and WOZ gives a sheepish wave.

dialogue: Give yourselves a treat and ask Woz if he happens to have the correct time.
I have the correct time and we’re running out of it. “A great keyboard.”
A great keyboard and the coolest mouse you’ve ever seen. This is what those things look like today.

content.text: On the screen flashes a picture of a bulky PC. Some people in the rehearsal audience who are seeing the full production for the first time laugh.

dialogue: And now I’d like to show you what they’re going to look like tomorrow. This is the iMac.

content.text: STEVE yanks the dark silk sheet off an iMac as a pool of perfect light comes up on the table.
CHEERS and APPLAUSE from the APPLE EMPLOYEES.
STEVE clicks the mouse and the screen shows a lightning fast succession of applications complete with a heart-racing percussion score--
--after which the screen fills with the words “Hello (again).”
The hundred or so people sitting and standing around out in the house CLAP AND CHEER.

dialogue: That was cool. Why did I like that better than I usually do?

content.text: ANDREA CUNNINGHAM, the publicist from the Mac launch, is standing at the foot of the stage--
STEVE looks at her--

dialogue: I think she’s talking to one of you guys.
That’s what I’m--the exit signs were off!
We wired all the exit lights to our board, they go out for seven seconds with the cue and come back on again in theory.
No, we’re very certain it’s not. You want to see some quotes?

content.text: JOANNA shakes her head “no.”
STEVE takes a couple of stapled pieces of paper from ANDREA and as ANDREA turns around she mouths “I’m sorry” to JOANNA while JOANNA says--

dialogue: Pick it up from there please, we only have a couple of minutes so let’s just do the 360.
It’s Cue 84, right where we are, you’re bringing out the camera.
We’re gonna bring out a wireless camera we stole from Panasonic and show you what this looks like.

content.text: A CAMERA OPERATOR with a camera on his shoulder comes out from the wings and circles the iMac, showing a 360 degree picture on the big screen as STEVE describes and points to what we’re looking at.

dialogue: The whole thing is translucent, you can see into it.
How’s that for a compromise, Woz? You still can’t get into it but you can see into it.

We’ve put stereo speakers in front, infra red right up here, CD-ROM drive right in the middle, dual stereo headphone jacks and all the connectors are inside one beautiful little door here--Ethernet, USB.

content.text: The Apple employees CHEER. Obviously they’re not seeing the computer for the first time but it’s a proud and exciting day.

dialogue: Even though this is a full-blooded Macintosh, we’re targeting it for the number one use that consumers tell us they want a computer for, which is--

content.text: JOANNA comes down to meet him at the edge of the stage.

dialogue: Just stand in front of me. I want to look at these quotes but I don’t want Joel to know.

“A piece of hardware that blends sci-fi shimmer with the kitsch whimsy of a cocktail umbrella,” says Steven Levy in Newsweek. “It is not only the coolest looking computer introduced in years, but a chest-thumping statement that Silicon Valley’s original dream company is no longer somnambulant.”

content.text: STEVE takes a moment for himself...

dialogue: It’s a word, it means sleepwalking.
Steve, I’m sorry, we have to clear the house if we’re gonna start on time.
Everybody, that’s it. They’ve got to mop the stage, reset and open the house. I love you guys.

content.text: Everyone CHEERS--

dialogue: Andy, come on back a minute?

content.text: JOANNA walks up the step unit to the stage just as the step unit is being taken away. STEVE takes the paper from her as they head--
JOANNA hands back the quotes--

dialogue: Forbes calls it “...an industry- altering success.”
Why haven’t we ever slept together?
We’re not in love. Look here.
Nobody’s heard from him in five years but he did this.
“He has implemented the same simple strategy that made Apple so successful 15 years ago: make hit products and promote them with terrific marketing.”
Sightings of J.D. Salinger are more common than John Sculley.
I wasn’t being sarcastic, it was nice of him.
Do you ever talk to him?
You haven’t talked to him since ‘88?
I’d have told you if I did.
It doesn’t matter, I don’t want people thinking that they can cross me and then boom 15 years later I’m okay with it.
I was kidding, what’s wrong with you this morning?

content.text: STEVE and JOANNA open the heavy door that leads out into--
--where they start heading down toward Steve’s dressing room. We can HEAR the crowd in the lobby around the corner.

dialogue: You see how this door looks like this door? If you go through this door you’re backstage, if you go through this door you’re in a parking lot.
Did you hear what I just said?
I’m not worried I’m gonna accidentally walk into a parking lot.
I want to talk to you.
“The only thing Apple’s providing now is leadership in colors.”
What does Bill Gates have against me?
I don’t know, you’re both out of your minds. Listen to me--
He dropped out of a better school than I dropped out of--

content.text: They walk into--

dialogue: --but he is a tool bag and I’ll tell you why.
You’ve come to my apartment at 1AM and cleaned it so tell me where the boundary is.
If I give you some real projections will you promise not to repeat them from the stage?
What do you mean real projections, what have you been giving me?
We’ve been managing expectations so that you don’t not.
We’re going to sell a million units in the first 90 days, 20,000 a month after that.

content.text: STEVE looks at her for a moment and then smiles...

dialogue: See? You wait long enough and--

What’s more, 32% of the sales are going to go to people buying a computer for the first time and 12% are going to people using some kind of Windows machine--that’s what Bill Gates has against you--and it’ll be the fastest selling computer in history.

You brought the company back from life support after going through the misery of laying off 3,000 people and cutting 70% of the product line so Steven...it’s over...you’re going to win. It would be criminal not to enjoy this moment.
--I don’t like having less privacy than other people have.
Does being a multi-billionaire take some of the sting off that?
All Lisa did was give her blessing. Chrisann sold the house and--
And Lisa could have done what? File a complaint with the Department of Housing and Urban Development? How’s Lisa supposed to stop her mother from selling her own house?
That I bought for the two of them.
Voicing an objection would have been a step in the right direction.
You don’t think you’re having a bizarre overreaction to a 19-year old girl allowing her mother to list her own house?
You’re saying this is really because--how’s she supposed to stop her mother--that particular mother-- from
She gave Chrisann her blessing to sell the house and she did it to spite me.
I don’t care if she put a pipe bomb in the water heater, you’re gonna fix it now.
She’s been acting weird for months. She’s turned on me.

content.text: And JOANNA shoves STEVE--

dialogue: Fix it or I quit, how ‘bout that? I quit and you never see me again, how ‘bout that?
This is me, tell me what’s wrong with you this morning.

What’s been wrong with me for 19 years?! I’ve been a witness and I tell you I’ve been complicit. I love you, Steven, you know how much. I love that you don’t care how much money a person makes, you care what they make. But what you make isn’t supposed to be the best part of you. When you’re a father, that’s what’s supposed to be the best part of you and it’s caused me two decades of agony, Steve, that it is, for you, the worst. It is a little thing, a very small thing, it’s not a big deal, fix it, fix it now or you can contact me at my new job working anywhere I want.
I don’t happen to think it is a little deal. She knew--
I mean “no,” the house has nothing to do with why you’re angry at Lisa.
I assure you, the house has everything to do with
Have you ever heard the phrase “Reality distortion field”?
Comes home from school, puts her bags down, goes straight to her friends’.
As it applies to you? As in “Steve’s reality distortion field”?
You’re getting a little prosecutorial and you’re crossing some lines.
I’ll cross whatever I please. You’ve heard it?
I’ve heard it, I’ve read it, it’s been sung to me by Joan Baez. What you call a reality distortion field-- and I’m pretty sure you’re the one who coined the phrase--is the reason we’re here.
If I traded in my bank account for a dollar on every time someone told me something was impossible I’d come out ahead.
My problem? It sure isn’t the house.
It’s that you told her you weren’t going to pay for Harvard. That child--that earnest, unironic kid--
She told you I wasn’t paying her tuition?
I should have hit you with something heavy a long time ago.
Lisa told you I wasn’t paying her tuition?
He wrote Harvard a check for twenty- five thousand to cover the semester. Isn’t that why--
Isn’t that why you just asked to see him?
No I asked to see him about--this is un--
Did you tell her you weren’t paying for college?

--because her mother, who was also her landlord--Hertzfeld--I was ranting! I was, you know, I was just talking! You think I would--I was pissed off because Lisa was trying to piss me off, Joanna! That was her intent! I don’t know how I ended up the bad--
Hertzfeld wrote a check to Har--to pay for--is she here yet?

content.text: STEVE’s gotten himself together.

dialogue: Can you have someone bring her back?
You know, my grandmother used to--
I don’t give a shit, Yentl!
Thank you. And if you see Hertzfeld--

content.text: There’s a KNOCK at the door--

dialogue: Speak of the devil’s chief engineer.

content.text: ANDY comes in as JOANNA’s leaving--
JOANNA exits and closes the door behind her.

dialogue: I think I know why I’m here.
Did you send the check yet?
So Harvard got a tuition check from Andy Hertzfeld to pay for Lisa?
I don’t think they look that carefully, I don’t think they’d notice the check didn’t come from you.
Close one. This was almost embarrassing for me.
I’ll wire you the money today.
I understand how you feel and I do apologize, I do, but let me tell you my thinking.
I can’t even think of an appropriate analogy to describe
I knew you guys would fix things, you always do, but in the meantime if the money wasn’t there she’d miss a semester of school.
And she’d have to tell her friends why. And she needed things, she needed socks.
It’s cold in Cambridge, she needed warm socks.
Well I gave her money for socks.
You don’t get to deputize yourself as her interim--
--you don’t get to override my decisions. Do you understand? You don’t get to act like you’re her father.
The fuck did you just say to me?!
I’ve known her since she was six. I also consider--Chrisann’s a friend outside of what you and I--outside of our
So you’re like a family advisor.
Then you probably know Lisa’s been seeing a therapist.
I’m fascinated by what you think is and isn’t your business.
Lisa’s been going to a therapist and she likes it and would love for you and Chrisann to go with her.
And the reason you know that is that you’re the one who recommended the therapist.
I know a guy, he specializes in--
No, I mean, you’re the one who recommended that she see a therapist.
I--you know what, it was a while ago and I don’t remember how the whole--who said what to--
You told Chrisann that Lisa should see a therapist.
Steve, you’re stigmatizing--it’s not--my thing was how can it hurt?
What was the reason you gave?
What was the reason you gave Chrisann why Lisa should see a therapist?
I don’t remember. We were talking and I said--it was pretty much what I just said, that it certainly couldn’t hurt.
You didn’t say Lisa needed a strong male role model?
I think it’s a miracle she’s not robbing banks with the Symbionese Liberation Army. There is no reason in the world why she should be nice. But she is. So I helped. Because somebody had to.
I’ll wire the money to you this afternoon.

content.text: ANDY gets up and heads to the door...

dialogue: You threatened me a long time ago.
A long time ago. You threatened me once.
People are attracted to people with talent and people without it find that threatening. Maybe you should see a therapist. It certainly couldn’t hurt.
I meant you literally threatened me. At Flint, right before the Mac launch.
I was recompiling, I was trying to debug the voice demo and you said if I couldn’t find a solution you’d call me out in front of the audience.
Why do you want people to dislike you?
I don’t want people to dislike me. I’m indifferent to whether they dislike me.
Well...since it doesn’t matter? I always have.
Really? I’ve always liked you a lot. That’s too bad.

content.text: ANDY exits.
STEVE stands there a moment...then launches into a practice run of a section of the presentation so he can wipe away what just happened.

dialogue: What is remarkable, what’s hard to fathom but true is that for a given clock rate a power PC chip is twice as fast as a Pentium II chip.
is twice as fast as a 266 Megahertz Pentium II or a 266 G3 is equal to about 500 Megahertz. Take a look at BYTE Magazine’s BYTE Marks, the gold standard for--
There’s a KNOCK at the door--

content.text: JOANNA enters.

dialogue: I sent someone into the lobby. They found her and--
She said she’d rather not come back.
You can’t. You can’t, you can’t. It’ll be a scene out of Hard Day’s Night.

content.text: JOEL PFORZHEIMER knocks on the open door--

dialogue: Andy said it was okay to come back.
I need one of them to change their name, I can’t do this forever.
It doesn’t matter what I call them. I know who I’m talking about when I’m talking. I need everyone else to call them different names.

content.text: STEVE takes JOANNA out into--
--and out of hearing distance where he speaks quietly.

dialogue: Go get her for me please. I just talked to Andy...Hertzfeld...and I’m just trying to scrub this out of my brain with Drano but I do want to talk to Lisa.

content.text: JOANNA heads down the corridor and STEVE watches her go. Without turning around, JOANNA points to the two doors as she passes them--
He goes back into--

dialogue: I’m feeling good, Joel, how about you?
I don’t think I could be in your business. It changes too quickly.
Well I’d hang on ‘cause yours is about to start changing pretty quickly too.
This is the third time in 14 years I’m writing about you.
What do you think so far?

content.text: ANDREA CUNNINGHAM sticks her head in the door--

dialogue: Excuse me. Avie’s asking for you, he has a new shark slide.
You want to come backstage for a second?

content.text: They head out into--
The hall is lined with blown up photographs of Ghandi, John Lennon, Louis Armstrong, etc.--all from the “Think Different” campaign.

dialogue: Alan Turing. He single handedly won World War II and for an encore invented the computer but he won’t be part of the campaign.
‘Cause you just had to ask me who he was.

content.text: STEVE opens the door and they walk into--
--where AVIE and his ENGINEERS are doing last minute runs and adjustments on the iMacs that’ll be running the demo in a few minutes.
And we can HEAR the CROWD out in the house...

dialogue: Can I see a new shark?

content.text: AVIE hits a key and the screen fills with a picture of a PowerBook G3 Laptop and a great white shark with its teeth bared.

dialogue: I like it better than the old shark.
How many sharks did you go through?
You know what’s special about this shark?
No, I’m really asking ‘cause it looks exactly like the other 38 sharks to me.
Let me see it with the cue. From the profile.
This is a side profile here. And this is what it looks like from the back. And one more thing: It eats Pentium notebooks as a light snack.
This is the shark, I really like it. Nobody gets it right the first time but I should have been shown this shark 15, 20 fish ago.
He killed himself by taking a bite of a poison Apple. Alan Turing.
Yeah. There should be statues of that man. His name should be on the lips of schoolchildren.
The rainbow flag Apple with a bite taken out, that’s where it came from?
No, we picked it off a list of friendly sounding words. But wouldn’t it be great if that had been the story behind it?
Anyway, I can’t use him in the campaign.

content.text: WOZ, sitting out in the house, calls up to the stage--
STEVE looks out...

dialogue: I kind of liked the last shark.
I wanted to ask you a favor.
My friend, a long time ago you asked me a favor before a product launch and I said no. You wanted me to acknowledge the Apple II and I--
Hang on. If you’re about to say you were wrong I want to prepare this reporter.
I was one hundred percent right and you were spectacularly wrong but I still owe you a favor so name it.
But it can’t be about acknowledging the Apple II team.
--I’m trying to remember that a 300 Megahertz G3 chip is equal to a

content.text: STEVE searches his mind a moment for the path of least resistance when he sees JOANNA come backstage--
STEVE goes over to JOANNA--

dialogue: She’s sitting with her friends and she said she’d rather not come back.
Okay, tell her--take her aside, I don’t want to embarrass her in front of her friends, but tell her I just scared the shit out of Andy and this time nobody’s paying her fuckin’--

content.text: JOANNA gives him a look--

dialogue: Alright, don’t say that. But do your thing where you sound old and wise because of the broad, tragic European canvas of your life.
You know I wasn’t born in a 19th Century shtetl, right?

content.text: STEVE goes back to WOZ as JOANNA heads out the door.
STEVE continues to WOZ--

dialogue: Just the top guys. The ones who are getting laid off.

Listen. Okay? Last year Apple lost one billion dollars. I don’t even know how that’s possible. You were less than 90 days from being insolvent. I had three different accountants try to explain it to me. The whole place has to be streamlined.
Start with two of the accountants.
Joel, come with me, we’re gonna--
I started with the Apple II team, because we don’t, you know, make that anymore.
You will not blow me off right now! The top
There are no top guys! On the Apple II team there are no top guys. They’re B Players and B Players discourage the A Players and I want the A Players at Apple and not Dell.
They’re not B Players and I’m a better judge of
Less than 90 days to insolvency. In part because somebody thought the Newton wasn’t a box of garbage.
You guys designed and shipped a little box of garbage while I was gone.
--I’m talking about the Apple II which isn’t just a crucial part of this company’s history, it’s a crucial part of the history of personal computing--
--and the least you can do if you’re gonna downsize these people--
They’re gonna live in the biggest houses of anyone on the unemployment line.
--is to acknowledge them, just acknowledge them and the--
--and the Apple II during this launch.
This whole place was built by the Apple II. You were built by the Apple II.

As a matter of fact I was destroyed by the Apple II and its open system so that hackers and hobbyists could build ham radios or something and then it nearly destroyed Apple when you spent all your money on it and developed a grand total of no new products.

The little box of garbage? You guys came up with the Newton and you, like, want people to know that? This is a product launch, it’s not a luncheon, and the last thing I want to do is connect the iMac--

--to the only successful product this company’s ever made? I’m sorry to be blunt it happens to be the truth. The Lisa was a failure. The Macintosh was a failure. I don’t like talking like this but I’m tired of being Ringo when I know I was John.
And I’m tired of being patronized by you.
You think John became John by winning a raffle, Woz? You think he tricked somebody or hit George Harrison over the head? He was John because he was John.
He was John because he wrote “Ticket to Ride” and I wrote the Apple II.
Everybody, I want to clear the--

Nobody moves! You made a beautiful board which, by the way, you were willing to give out for free so don’t tell me how you built Apple. If it weren’t for me you’d be the easiest “A” at Homestead High School.
These people live and die by your praise and here’s your chance. Acknowledge that something good happened that you weren’t in the room for.
Steve, do it. It’s right. It’s just...it’s right.
Then let me put it another way.
I don’t believe there’s a man who’s done more to advance the democratization that comes with personal computing than I have but you’ve never had any respect for me, now why is that?
I’d at least consider the possibility that it’s because you’ve never had any for me.

content.text: JOANNA’s come out in the house and sees what’s happening--

dialogue: What the hell is going on?

content.text: STEVE nods...then turns back to WOZ--

dialogue: You came a half-inch from putting this company out of business, now who do I see about that? I’m letting you keep your job. You get a pass.

When people used to ask me what the difference was between me and Steve Jobs I’d say Steve was the big picture guy and I liked a solid workbench. When people ask me what the difference is now I just say Steve’s an asshole. The things you make are better than you are, brother.
That’s the idea, brother. And knowing that?...That’s the difference.
It’s not binary. You can be decent and gifted at the same time.

content.text: STEVE starts to walk away from WOZ but then turns around--

dialogue: I once asked Paul McCartney what made the Beatles sound like the Beatles and you know what he said? The drumming.

content.text: WOZ has waited years to say this and for all those years he hoped he wouldn’t have to.

dialogue: Maybe one day you’ll make something and know for sure. ‘Cause the little box of garbage? Was one little box of garbage more than you’ve ever made in your life.

content.text: STEVE holds a moment, nods and heads over to JOANNA, who’s clocked this whole last exchange.

dialogue: It’s like 5 minutes before every launch everyone goes to a bar, gets drunk and tells me what they really think.
She’s coming to your dressing room.

content.text: They head out into--

dialogue: I told you to make up with Lisa, I didn’t say you had to settle every blood feud you have. Who lives that long?
The last time blood feuds weren’t settled I lost the cover of Time. Though for the life of me I still don’t know what the hell Dan Kottke was mad at me about.
Kottke didn’t lose you the cover of Time.
Would you like me to demonstrate your capacity to be wrong when you’re certain you’re right?
Dan Kottke told Michael Moritz that I was denying--

content.text: They walk into--

dialogue: No, it was a sculpture of a computer. It was a sculpture. Time would have had to have commissioned it months in advance.
You were never in the conversation for Man of the Year. Nobody lost you anything. So what else are you sure about?
I don’t know how I could have missed that.

content.text: STEVE takes this in...it’s really rocked his world...
STEVE’s a little shaken up...

dialogue: I don’t know how I could have missed that.

content.text: JOANNA looks at STEVE silently. She’s not going to help him this time. Then--

dialogue: Don’t try to win an argument with Lisa. Just say you were wrong. A kid should hear their dad say, “I was wrong” once in a while.

content.text: There’s a KNOCK on the door...
The door opens a little and SCULLEY sticks his head in--

There’s a moment of shock as STEVE and SCULLEY take in the sight of each other. Sculley’s always been a handsome man--a healthy, well-scrubbed, Connecticut guy--but he was sent to Florida much too young. And he’s been living a secluded life as the guy who traded Babe Ruth. STEVE can see that.

dialogue: John, get in, get out of the hall.
I was taken in a side entrance. I’ll go out the same way, no one’ll see me.
I’m good, John. I’m just surprised to see you.
Everyone here really appreciates the quote you gave Forbes, you didn’t have to do that.
If you want I can slip you in the back once the house lights go out.
I’m just here to say good luck.
You’ve just got a couple of minutes.

content.text: JOANNA gives SCULLEY a kiss on the cheek, then wipes off any lipstick marks. She loves that he came.
She exits.

dialogue: So I brought you a present.

content.text: SCULLEY hands STEVE a box...STEVE smiles...

dialogue: Don’t take it out of the box. You’ll be able to sell it. Which is more than I can say.
What? Yeah. No, it’s just something Joanna pointed out to me. I missed something so obvious about--it doesn’t matter.

Look, Wall Street’s gonna sit back and wait to see how you do as CEO, don’t let any fluctuation bother you for the first 12 months. Day traders are gonna respond to every-- I don’t need to school you.
Is this your way of telling me I shouldn’t have killed the Newton?
Well you shouldn’t have killed it for spite. That’s bad business, don’t do that.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:
An unimpressive-looking Mediterranean restaurant in Berkeley. STEVE and SCULLEY sit at a booth.

dialogue: Alright 1957, and IBM passes up the chance to buy a young company that’s just developed a technology called xerography.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: I don’t know why you’ve always been interested in my adoption history but you said it’s not like someone looked at me and gave me back but that is what happened.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: Then 10 years later, DEC invents the mini-computer and IBM dismisses it as too small to do serious computing.
They weren’t close enough to the future to see it by then?
DEC becomes a billion dollar corporation and IBM decides they should maybe get into the computer business.

content.text: The owner of the restaurant, a balding Syrian-American named JANDALI comes over to the table.

dialogue: Jandali, say hello to John Sculley. Jandali owns this place and John’s the CEO of Pepsi but I’m trying to get him to move to Cupertino and put a dent in the universe.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: A lawyer couple adopted me first and then gave me back after a month. They changed their mind.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: Do you eat vegan as well?
Why don’t you start us off with a Mediterranean lettuce salad with purslane, mint, cucumbers--

content.text: JANDALI heads away as STEVE continues--

dialogue: Ten years later, 1977, and another young company called Apple invents the first personal computer--
--and IBM dismisses it as unimportant to their business.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Then my parents adopted me. My biological mother had stipulated that whoever took me had to be college educated, wealthy and Catholic. Paul and Clara Jobs were none of those things so my biological mother wouldn’t sign the adoption papers.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: In ‘81 the Apple II becomes the world’s most popular computer and now IBM gets into the game with the
Apple and IBM each invest upwards of 50 million in R&D and another 50 million in advertising.
It’s a shake down. They want to get rid of the weaker companies.
The weaker companies are going bankrupt. IBM wants it all.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: There was a legal battle that went on for a while and my mother said she refused to love me for the first year, you know in case they had to give me back.
You can’t refuse to love someone, Steve.
Yeah it turns out you can.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: And now IBM’s got its guns trained on you.
Apple is the only thing standing between Blue and industry domination.
You said you were going to tell me what you have in the testing stage.

The most efficient animal on the planet is a condor. The most inefficient animals on the planet are humans. But a human with a bicycle becomes the most efficient animal. And the right computer--a friendly, easy computer that isn’t an eyesore but rather sits on your desk with the beauty of a tensor lamp--the right computer will be a bicycle for the mind. A beautiful object--perfect geometry, perfect finish, something you want to look at and have in your home. Flawless. And then a personal computer becomes an interpersonal computer. And what if instead of it being in the right hands, it was in everyone’s hands? Everyone in the world.
We’d be talking about the most tectonic shift in the status quo since--
And you’re telling me you have the right computer?
It’s called the Macintosh. You and I can see to it that IBM doesn’t control the information age. We can see to it that Orwell was wrong.

content.text: JANDALI comes over and sets down some food.

dialogue: There’s the spot. “1984 doesn’t have to be like ‘1984.’”

content.text: STEVE and SCULLEY look at each other...the beginning of a great adventure.
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: What the hell can a one month old do that’s so bad his parents give him back?
Nothing. There’s nothing a one month old can do.
Have you ever thought about trying to find your biological father?
I’ve met my biological father. For that matter, so have you.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:
And we see an earlier moment all over again--

dialogue: Jandali, say hello to John Sculley.

content.text: CUT BACK TO:
SCULLEY’s gone white...

dialogue: I know. The odds were beyond astronomical.

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:

dialogue: Do you eat vegan as well?

content.text: CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: No. In fact he bragged to Mona that Steve Jobs comes in the restaurant all the time.
Do you go to his rest--

content.text: QUICK CUT TO:
STEVE and a group of guests are having a boisterous conversation with STEVE joyfully eating something off someone else’s plate--loving the food.
CUT BACK TO:

dialogue: Don’t you think you should talk to him?
He’d probably find a reason to sue me.

content.text: SCULLEY sees STEVE clearly...maybe for the first time.

dialogue: John, if you’re here about your legacy you need to form a line behind Wozniak.
Woz is gonna be fine. I’m the guy who fired Steve Jobs.

content.text: There’s a KNOCK at the door--
STEVE stops at the door--

dialogue: Did I do this? Screw it up?

content.text: SCULLEY takes a moment and then says something he’s not sure he means--

dialogue: Let’s let it go now. It has to be time.
I killed the Newton because of the stylus. If you’re holding a stylus you can’t use the other five that are attached to your wrist.
The things we could have done together.
God, the things we could have done.

content.text: STEVE opens the door and walks out into--
The hallway’s a little crowded now with Apple employees lining the walls including JOANNA. They’ll serve as an escort backstage but right now, coming down the hall toward STEVE--

--is LISA. At 19 she’s a beautiful young woman with a striking resemblance to her father. She’s wearing a coat and has the same headphones around her neck that we saw her in when she was nine. She’s nothing like a stereotypical teenager--she’s without affect and only uses irony in very small doses. We’re aware that she’s ill at ease and self- protective and uncomfortable.
She walks down the hallway which is lined with “Think Different” posters that have a picture of the iMac.

STEVE watches her walk toward him--he’s too worn out now to have a real confrontation with her but he’ll be slowly forced into it. He takes his arm to move her to the side of the corridor and he does his best to speak privately while almost surrounded by people.

dialogue: I’m paying your tuition. Are you crazy? Of course I’m paying your tuition.
I must have misunderstood when you said you weren’t paying my tuition.
You and your mom selling the house was a hostile thing to do and you
She needs a doctor, she has a sinus infection.
She’s had the same sinus infection since 1988.
I’m gonna take care of my mother, I’m sorry if that angers you.
It does anger me ‘cause you’re a kid and it’s not your job to take care of your mother.

content.text: This just went to the next level and JOANNA’s just seen that...

dialogue: Guys step away please and give them some room.

content.text: Everyone creates a little more space but total privacy is really impossible right now.

dialogue: When your mom is 90 and can’t feed herself you can take care of her. But right now she’s 45, perfectly healthy and can’t feed herself. You’re supposed to work hard in school and be 19 and that’s it. I’ll take care of your mother.
What the hell do you want from me?
Look, I bought her a house for seven-hundred thousand dollars, it’s worth twice that much today and she sold it for two magic rocks and a bowl of soup!
She used that money to travel through Europe--
It was her money which you make her beg for.
Oh don’t talk to me about--going to Andy and asking him for the money. That was so off-the-charts over
I did not do that. Andy came to me.

content.text: STEVE looks around at the dozen or so people that are too nearby for comfort--

dialogue: Everybody have an opinion on this?
--in 30 seconds you’re going to be late.
I’m callous ‘cause I’m not sending a Gulf Stream to the Pasteur Institute to fetch the finest sinus specialists in all the land?!
She spends the money on antiques. And then sells them for a fraction of what she paid. And she does it with money I gave to her for you--
You came to me hysterical when you were
(13, asking if you could live with me)
Thirteen was the second time I asked you.
--screaming at you every day or not speaking to you for weeks at a time-- the stress of her life as a spiritual healer--
I don’t believe I said you’re a bad guy but if I did I’m sorry.
Something happened to you at school. Some first semester core class that all freshman are required to take, some--

content.text: This has stopped STEVE in his tracks...

dialogue: I have internet access at school, I read an old copy of Time and I asked my mom some questions about my family history.

content.text: STEVE is frozen for a moment...

dialogue: That was...Time wrote a mangled piece of journal--you were never supposed to read that--
I had two different Harvard statisticians try to reverse engineer the equation you came up with to prove that 28% of American men could be my father.

content.text: LISA can’t help but raise her voice a little. She’s not someone who likes dramatics but she’s upset now. There’s no way the others are going to be able to avoid hearing this.

dialogue: My mother may be a troubled woman but what’s your excuse?

That’s why I’m not impressed with your story, dad. It’s that you knew and you didn’t do anything about it and that makes you an unconscionable coward. And not for nothin’ but “Think” is a verb making “Different” an adverb. You’re asking people to “Think DifferentLY”. And you can talk about the Bauhaus movement and Braun and simplicity is sophistication and Issey Miyake uniforms and Bob Dylan lyrics all you want, but that thing--
(pointing at one of the posters of the iMac)
--looks like Judy Jetson’s Easy Bake Oven!

content.text: LISA walks away and out the side door that goes to the parking lot.
There’s a frozen silence for a moment before--

dialogue: There is no way in the world that’s not my kid.

content.text: STEVE looks at JOANNA who looks kindly back. After a moment, ANDREA interrupts with--
Everyone begins to head to the door leading to the stage. We see STEVE’s hand grab the door handle and turn it as we--
CUT TO:

STEVE’s walked out the parking lot door to go after Lisa. We can see JOANNA and ANDREA CUNNINGHAM and the others. We’re on the side of the auditorium and while the lot is filled there are no people except LISA who’s making her way to her car.
STEVE watches her go and then makes a decision--
LISA turns around.

dialogue: You know what Lisa stood for?
The computer, the Lisa, you know what it stood for?
I’m sorry I said that about the iMac, it’s not what I really think.
Behind my back, at the office, you know what it stood for?
Local Integrated System Architecture. I was five, why couldn’t you just lie?
I did. It stood for “Lisa. Colon. Invented Stupid Acronym.”
Of course it was named after you, are you daffy! Local Integrated System Architecture doesn’t even mean anything, of course it was named after you.
Why did you say it wasn’t all those years?
Why did you say you weren’t my father?

content.text: LISA stands there a moment, then checks her watch--

dialogue: You can’t start late. It’s after nine.
I know I didn’t want to be yoked to your mom but--
And you can belittle my mother all you want but she always made dinner for me and she always took me to school.
Feeding you and taking you to school is kind of the baseline of parenting, Lisa, it’s actually a legal obligation. Don’t devalue yourself like that, don’t do that.
But you’re right, she did. And I didn’t.
I‘m using “Different” as a noun, smartass. Like “Think Victory.” Or “Vote Freedom.”
The Apple chapter of the Harvard Alumni Association tells me you’re writing for the Crimson.
No, I mean now, I’d like to read one of your essays now.
That’s--c’mon, you’ve got to go on stage.
Suit yourself but the iMac will not be launched until you give me one of your essays so the world is waiting for you.
It’s not like I have one on me.
Somewhere in that backpack is one of your essays. Dump the contents on the ground and if I’m wrong I’ll buy you a Cabriolet.

content.text: LISA looks at him, not believing this...she unzips one of the pockets of her backpack and things start falling out and as she tries to collect them more things start falling out until everything’s on the ground.
STEVE watches as LISA, unhurriedly, collects her things and puts them back. It’s going to take a while.
STEVE just watches this, smiles and shakes his head...

dialogue: I just spilled some...don’t laugh at me.

content.text: She finds the essay and holds it out. All she wants is for her dad to be proud of her.

dialogue: It hasn’t been published yet, I just finished but it’s a first draft and it reads like one.

content.text: STEVE takes the essay, crumpled and coffee-stained...STEVE sees the byline on the essay--”LISA BRENNAN-JOBS.”
STEVE can’t help but take in the sight of her using his name. He’d stare at it forever if he wasn’t interrupted by--
He looks up at her...

dialogue: Why don’t you just read it after. You can give it your full attention.
Okay. But you should know that the Bay Area is strewn with the broken spirits of people who couldn’t handle my full attention.

content.text: And this makes LISA crack up. She really has a good laugh and that makes her father smile. She picks up her backpack--
LISA starts to walk off--

dialogue: I’m gonna put music in your pocket.

content.text: LISA turns around--

dialogue: A hundred songs. A thousand songs. Five hundred songs. Somewhere between five hundred and a thousand songs. Right in your pocket. Because I can’t stand looking at that inexplicable Walkman anymore. You’re carrying around a brick playing a cassette tape. We’re not savages. So I’m gonna put a thousand songs in your pocket.

content.text: And now we HEAR the musical intro to “Both Sides Now,” but it’s not the version we’re used to. This is the one Lisa was describing when she was nine. It’s a beautiful male/female duet with heartbreaking harmonies, more mature, wiser and haunted.

dialogue: Mm-hm. All I have to do really is wipe out the record business as we know it and we’ll be all set.
You want to watch from backstage?

content.text: LISA joins her father and the two of them walk to the side entrance of the building.

dialogue: This is the last semester you get to take dumb classes.
I don’t take “History of Food.” And you gave me my Walkman, I like it.
Well cherish it ‘cause it’s not gonna be around much longer.

content.text: They walk into--
--where everyone’s waiting. We can HEAR the rock concert-like stomping and clapping from the audience. “Both Sides Now” continues--
JOANNA walks STEVE and LISA--
--where the energy of the audience is louder. The STAGE MANAGER is waiting as is the WOMAN at the PA microphone.
STEVE and LISA stand there a moment...
STEVE shakes his head “no.” He takes a moment and then nods a little to the STAGE MANAGER--”I’m ready, let’s go.”
The AUDIENCE begins CLAPPING in anticipation--
The theater goes dark and the CLAPPING gets louder--
STAGE MANAGER (CONT’D)
On the giant screen the “Think Different” commercial starts playing to THUNDEROUS CHEERS from the AUDIENCE. We’ll HEAR it but NEVER SEE IT.

We HEAR the audio as “Both Sides Now” continues. The famous audio only serves as background. What we’re watching is everyone--everyone but STEVE--taken by the ad. STEVE’s taken by other things he’s remembering. One of them’s Lisa.

dialogue: Here’s to the crazy ones. The misfits. The rebels. The troublemakers.

content.text: STEVE’s standing in the dark next to LISA listening to these words. We MOVE IN SLOWLY on his face as he prepares to go on.

dialogue: The round pegs in the square holes. The ones who see things differently.

content.text: And we start to INTERCUT with various people out in the house, which is packed with 2,600 eager people--ANDY HERTZFELD...WOZ taking his seat...

dialogue: They’re not fond of rules. And they have no respect for the status quo. You can quote them, disagree with them, glorify or vilify them.

content.text: AVIE TEVANIAN...ANDREA CUNNINGHAM...

dialogue: About the only thing you can’t do is ignore them. Because they change things. They push the human race forward.

content.text: JOANNA slips in the back...with SCULLEY...

dialogue: And while some may see them as the crazy ones, we see genius.

content.text: And we’re backstage on STEVE and LISA again as “Both Sides Now” continues over. Is the song regretful like Lisa said, or does Steve still have a chance to fix himself?

dialogue: Because the people who think they’re crazy enough to change the world are the ones who do.
You remember that painting you did here on the original Mac?

content.text: LISA thinks...and then shakes her head “no.”
And LISA hears this and then wipes a tear from her eye with her sleeve.
The AUDIENCE goes crazy as the PA WOMAN says into the microphone--
HARD CUT TO:
BLACK
